{"uri": "2024-05-344325685", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-03", "time": "18:56:27", "dateTime": "2024-05-03T18:56:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-03T16:00:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9058823585510254, "url": "https://tribtown.com/2024/05/03/democratic-us-rep-henry-cuellar-of-texas-and-his-wife-are-indicted-over-ties-to-azerbaijan/", "title": "Democratic US Rep. Henry Cuellar of Texas and his wife are indicted over ties to Azerbaijan", "body": "FILE - Rep. Henry Cuellar, D-Texas, speaks during a hearing of the Homeland Security Subcommittee of the House Committee on Appropriations with Homeland Security Secretary Alejandro Mayorkas on Capitol Hill, April 10, 2024, in Washington. In a statement released Friday, May 3, Cuellar denied any wrongdoing amid reports of pending indictments related to the former [...]\n\nWASHINGTON (AP) -- Democratic U.S. Rep. Henry Cuellar of Texas and his wife were indicted on conspiracy and bribery charges and taken into custody Friday in connection with a U.S. Department of Justice probe into ties between American business leaders and the former Soviet republic of Azerbaijan.\n\nFrom 2014 to 2021, Cuellar and his wife accepted nearly $600,000 in bribes from an Azerbaijan-controlled energy company and a bank in Mexico, and in exchange, Cuellar agreed to advance the interests of the country and the bank in the U.S., according to the indictment.\n\nAmong other things, Cuellar agreed to influence legislation favorable to Azerbaijan and deliver a pro-Azerbaijan speech on the floor of the U.S. House, the indictment states.\n\nThe Department of Justice said the couple surrendered to authorities on Friday and were taken into custody.\n\nThe longtime congressman released a statement Friday saying he and his wife, Imelda Cuellar, \"are innocent of these allegations.\"\n\n\"Everything I have done in Congress has been to serve the people of South Texas,\" Cuellar said. \"Before I took action, I proactively sought legal advice from the House Ethics Committee, who gave me more than one written opinion, along with an additional opinion from a national law firm.\n\n\"Furthermore, we requested a meeting with the Washington D.C. prosecutors to explain the facts and they refused to discuss the case with us or hear our side.\"\n\nNeither Cuellar nor his attorney immediately responded to calls seeking comment on the matter.\n\nThe payments to the couple went through a Texas-based shell company owned by Imelda Cuellar and two of the couple's children, according to the indictment. That company received payments from the Azerbaijan energy company of $25,000 per month under a \"sham contract,\" purportedly in exchange for unspecified strategic consulting and advising services.\n\n\"In reality, the contract was a sham used to disguise and legitimate the corrupt agreement between Henry Cuellar and the government of Azerbaijan,\" the indictment states.\n\nImelda Cuellar sent a falsified invoice to the Azerbaijan energy company's Washington, D.C., office under the agreement, stating her work was complete.\n\n\"In fact, Imedla Cuellar had performed little or no legitimate work under the contract,\" the indictment says.\n\nCuellar was at one time the co-chair of the Congressional Azerbaijan Caucus.\n\nThe FBI searched the congressman's house in the border city of Laredo in 2022, and Cuellar's attorney at that time said Cuellar was not the target of that investigation. That search was part of a broader investigation related to Azerbaijan that saw FBI agents serve a raft of subpoenas and conduct interviews in Washington, D.C., and Texas, a person with direct knowledge of the probe previously told The Associated Press. The person was not authorized to discuss it publicly and spoke on condition of anonymity.\n\nFederal disclosures show that the nine-term congressman traveled to Azerbaijan in 2013. Two years later, Cuellar's office announced an agreement between a Texas university and an organization called the Assembly of Friends of Azerbaijan for the purposes of collaborating on oil and gas {"uri": "2024-05-344314990", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-03", "time": "18:40:29", "dateTime": "2024-05-03T18:40:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-03T18:22:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9058823585510254, "url": "https://www.republicworld.com/world-news/us/us-democratic-lawmaker-wife-indicted-in-bribery-case-over-alleged-azerbaijan-ties", "title": "US Democratic Lawmaker, Wife Indicted in Bribery Case Over Alleged Azerbaijan Ties", "body": "US Democratic Representative from Texas, Henry Cuellar, has been accused of accepting bribes from Azerbaijani entities. | Image:AP\n\nWashington: Democratic US Representative Henry Cuellar of Texas and his wife were indicted on conspiracy and bribery charges Friday in connection with a US Department of Justice probe into ties between American business leaders and the former Soviet republic of Azerbaijan.\n\nFrom 2014 to 2021, Cuellar and his wife accepted nearly $600,000 in bribes from an Azerbaijan-controlled energy company and a bank in Mexico, and in exchange, Cuellar agreed to advance the interests of the country and the bank in the US, according to the indictments.\n\nAmong other things, Cuellar agreed to influence legislation favorable to Azerbaijan and deliver a pro-Azerbaijan speech on the floor of the US House, the indictment states.\n\nThe longtime congressman released a statement Friday saying he and his wife, Imelda Cuellar, \"are innocent of these allegations.\"\n\n\"Everything I have done in Congress has been to serve the people of South Texas,\" Cuellar said. \"Before I took action, I proactively sought legal advice from the House Ethics Committee, who gave me more than one written opinion, along with an additional opinion from a national law firm.\n\n\"Furthermore, we requested a meeting with the Washington DC prosecutors to explain the facts and they refused to discuss the case with us or hear our side.\"\n\nNeither Cuellar nor his attorney immediately responded to calls seeking comment on the matter. Officials with the US Department of Justice declined to discuss the matter.\n\nCuellar was at one time the co-chair of the Congressional Azerbaijan Caucus.\n\nThe FBI searched the congressman's house in the border city of Laredo in 2022, and Cuellar's attorney at that time said Cuellar was not the target of that investigation.\n\nThat search was part of a broader investigation related to Azerbaijan that saw FBI agents serve a raft of subpoenas and conduct interviews in Washington, DC, and Texas, a person with direct knowledge of the probe previously told The Associated Press.\n\nThe person was not authorised to discuss it publicly and spoke on condition of anonymity.\n\nFederal disclosures show that the nine-term congressman traveled to Azerbaijan in 2013. Two years later, Cuellar's office announced an agreement between a Texas university and an organisation called the Assembly of Friends of Azerbaijan for the purposes of collaborating on oil and gas research and education.\n\nCuellar, one of the last anti-abortion Democrats in Congress, narrowly defeated progressive challenger Jessica Cisneros by fewer than 300 votes in a primary race in 2022.", {"uri": "8110248140", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-03", "time": "20:38:25", "dateTime": "2024-05-03T20:38:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-03T20:38:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8941176533699036, "url": "https://www.castanet.net/news/World/485612/Democratic-US-Rep-Henry-Cuellar-of-Texas-and-his-wife-are-indicted-over-ties-to-Azerbaijan", "title": "Democratic US Rep. Henry Cuellar of Texas and his wife are indicted over ties to Azerbaijan - World News", "body": "Photo: The Canadian Press FILE - Rep. Henry Cuellar, D-Texas, speaks during a hearing of the Homeland Security Subcommittee of the House Committee on Appropriations with Homeland Security Secretary Alejandro Mayorkas on Capitol Hill, April 10, 2024, in Washington. In a statement released Friday, May 3, Cuellar denied any wrongdoing amid reports of pending indictments related to the former Soviet republic of Azerbaijan. (AP Photo/Mark Schiefelbein, File)\n\nDemocratic U.S. Rep. Henry Cuellar of Texas and his wife were indicted on conspiracy and bribery charges and taken into custody Friday in connection with a U.S. Department of Justice probe into the couple's ties to the former Soviet republic of Azerbaijan.\n\nFrom 2014 to 2021, Cuellar, 68, and his wife accepted nearly $600,000 in bribes from an Azerbaijan-controlled energy company and a bank in Mexico, and in exchange, Cuellar agreed to advance the interests of the country and the bank in the U.S., according to the indictment.\n\nAmong other things, Cuellar agreed to influence legislation favorable to Azerbaijan and deliver a pro-Azerbaijan speech on the floor of the U.S. House, the indictment states.\n\nThe Department of Justice said the couple surrendered to authorities on Friday and were taken into custody. They made an initial appearance before a federal judge in Houston and were each released on $100,000 bond, the DOJ said.\n\nThe longtime congressman released a statement Friday saying he and his wife, Imelda Cuellar, 67, \"are innocent of these allegations.\"\n\n\"Everything I have done in Congress has been to serve the people of South Texas,\" Cuellar said. \"Before I took action, I proactively sought legal advice from the House Ethics Committee, who gave me more than one written opinion, along with an additional opinion from a national law firm.\n\n\"Furthermore, we requested a meeting with the Washington D.C. prosecutors to explain the facts and they refused to discuss the case with us or hear our side.\"\n\nNeither Cuellar nor his attorney immediately responded to calls seeking comment on the matter.\n\nIn addition to bribery and conspiracy, the couple face charges including wire fraud conspiracy, acting as agents of foreign principals and money laundering. If convicted, they face up to decades in prison and forfeiture of any property linked to proceeds from the alleged scheme.\n\nThe payments to the couple initially went through a Texas-based shell company owned by Imelda Cuellar and two of the couple's children, according to the indictment. That company received payments from the Azerbaijan energy company of $25,000 per month under a \"sham contract,\" purportedly in exchange for unspecified strategic consulting and advising services.\n\n\"In reality, the contract was a sham used to disguise and legitimate the corrupt agreement between Henry Cuellar and the government of Azerbaijan,\" the indictment states.\n\nImelda Cuellar sent a falsified invoice to the Azerbaijan energy company's Washington, D.C., office under the agreement, stating her work was complete.\n\n\"In fact, Imelda Cuellar had performed little or no legitimate work under the contract,\" the indictment says.\n\nThe indictment also alleges an Azerbaijani diplomat referred to Henry Cuellar in text messages as \"el Jefe\" or \"boss,\" and also that a member of Cuellar's staff sent multiple emails to officials at the Department of State pressuring them to renew a U.S. passport for an Azerbaijani diplomat's daughter.\n\nCuellar was at one time the co-chair of the Congressional Azerbaijan Caucus.\n\nThe FBI searched the congressman's house in the border city of Laredo in 2022, and Cuellar's attorney at that time said Cuellar was not the target of that investigation. That search was part of a broader investigation related to Azerbaijan that saw FBI agents serve a raft of subpoenas and conduct interviews in Washington, D.C., and Texas, a person with direct knowledge of the probe previously told The Associated Press. The person was not authorized to discuss it publicly and spoke on condition of anonymity.\n\nCuellar, one of the last anti-abortion Democrats in Congress, narrowly defeated progressive challenger Jessica Cisneros by fewer than 300 votes in a primary race in 2022.", "source": {"uri": "castanet.net", "dataType": "news", "title": "Castanet"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": The person was not authorized to discuss it publicly and spoke on condition of anonymity.\n\nFederal disclosures show that the nine-term congressman traveled to Azerbaijan in 2013. research and education.\n\nCuellar, one of the last anti-abortion Democrats in Congress, narrowly defeated progressive challenger Jessica Cisneros by fewer than 300 votes in a primary race in 2022.", {"uri": "2024-05-344296335", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-03", "time": "18:13:04", "dateTime": "2024-05-03T18:13:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-03T17:55:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8901960849761963, "url": "https://www.register-herald.com/news/nation_world/democratic-us-rep-henry-cuellar-of-texas-and-his-wife-are-indicted-over-ties-to/article_ed7c4d8d-032a-57de-a7d6-3b8cb680288a.html", "title": "Democratic US Rep. Henry Cuellar of Texas and his wife are indicted over ties to Azerbaijan", "body": "Democratic U.S. Rep. Henry Cuellar of Texas and his wife have been indicted on conspiracy and bribery charges in connection with a federal probe into the ties of American business leaders with Azerbaijan\n\nWASHINGTON (AP) -- Democratic U.S. Rep. Henry Cuellar of Texas and his wife were indicted on conspiracy and bribery charges Friday in connection with a U.S. Department of Justice probe into ties between American business leaders and the former Soviet republic of Azerbaijan.\n\nFrom 2014 to 2021, Cuellar and his wife accepted nearly $600,000 in bribes from an Azerbaijan-controlled energy company and a bank in Mexico, and in exchange, Cuellar agreed to advance the interests of the country and the bank in the U.S., according to the indictments.\n\nAmong other things, Cuellar agreed to influence legislation favorable to Azerbaijan and deliver a pro-Azerbaijan speech on the floor of the U.S. House, the indictment states.\n\nThe longtime congressman released a statement Friday saying he and his wife, Imelda Cuellar, \"are innocent of these allegations.\"\n\n\"Everything I have done in Congress has been to serve the people of South Texas,\" Cuellar said. \"Before I took action, I proactively sought legal advice from the House Ethics Committee, who gave me more than one written opinion, along with an additional opinion from a national law firm.\n\n\"Furthermore, we requested a meeting with the Washington D.C. prosecutors to explain the facts and they refused to discuss the case with us or hear our side.\"\n\nNeither Cuellar nor his attorney immediately responded to calls seeking comment on the matter. Officials with the U.S. Department of Justice declined to discuss the matter.\n\nCuellar was at one time the co-chair of the Congressional Azerbaijan Caucus.\n\nThe FBI searched the congressman's house in the border city of Laredo in 2022, and Cuellar's attorney at that time said Cuellar was not the target of that investigation. That search was part of a broader investigation related to Azerbaijan that saw FBI agents serve a raft of subpoenas and conduct interviews in Washington, D.C., and Texas, a person with direct knowledge of the probe previously told The Associated Press. The person was not authorized to discuss it publicly and spoke on condition of anonymity.\n\nFederal disclosures show that the nine-term congressman traveled to Azerbaijan in 2013. Two years later, Cuellar's office announced an agreement between a Texas university and an organization called the Assembly of Friends of Azerbaijan for the purposes of collaborating on oil and gas research and education.\n\nCuellar, one of the last anti-abortion Democrats in Congress, narrowly defeated progressive challenger Jessica Cisneros by fewer than 300 votes in a primary race in 2022.e {"uri": "2024-05-344314576", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-03", "time": "18:40:13", "dateTime": "2024-05-03T18:40:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-03T18:21:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.886274516582489, "url": "https://www.aol.com/news/doj-expected-announce-indictment-texas-150101676.html", "title": "Texas Rep. Henry Cuellar and wife indicted on bribery and foreign influence charges", "body": "Texas Rep. Henry Cuellar and wife indicted on bribery and foreign influence chargesDaniel Barnes and Julie Tsirkin and Ryan Nobles and Rebecca Kaplan and Ken Dilanian and Scott WongMay 3, 2024 at 8:21 PM\n\nWASHINGTON -- The Justice Department on Friday released an indictment against longtime Rep. Henry Cuellar, D-Texas, and his wife, Imelda, charging the pair with bribery and money laundering related to their ties with an oil and gas company controlled by Azerbaijan and a bank in Mexico City.\n\nNBC News was first to report that the charges were coming.\n\nCuellar's home and campaign office in Laredo, Texas, were raided in January 2022 as part of a federal investigation into Azerbaijan and a group of U.S. businessmen who have ties to the country, law enforcement said at the time. His office had pledged to cooperate with the investigation. In April, Cuellar's lawyer, Joshua Berman, told some news outlets that federal authorities informed him he was not the target of the investigation.\n\nCuellar is a one-time co-chair of the Congressional Azerbaijan Caucus.\n\nIt wasn't immediately clear if the indictment was related to the 2022 raid. The Justice Department declined to comment.\n\nCuellar's staff were calling other member offices Friday seeking advice on how to handle the situation, one source with knowledge of those calls told NBC News.\n\nIn a statement Friday, Cuellar denied any wrongdoing, saying that he had \"proactively sought legal advice\" from the House Ethics Committee, which had issued \"more than one written opinion\" about the matter. Much of his statement focused on his wife, Imelda Cuellar, though it wasn't immediately clear why.\n\n\"I want to be clear that both my wife and I are innocent of these allegations. Everything I have done in Congress has been to serve the people of South Texas,\" Cuellar said in his statement, later adding: \"The actions I took in Congress were consistent with the actions of many of my colleagues and in the interest of the American people ...\"\n\n\"Imelda and I have been married for 32 years. On top of being an amazing wife and mother, she's an accomplished businesswoman with two degrees. She spent her career working with banking, tax, and consulting,\" he continued. \"The allegation that she is anything but qualified and hard working is both wrong and offensive.\"\n\nA defiant Cuellar also made clear he will seek re-election: \"Let me be clear, I'm running for re-election and will win this November.\"\n\nA year after the raid on his home -- which has not previously yielded arrests or charges -- Cuellar told the Texas Tribune: \"There has been no wrongdoing on my part. ... My focus remains the same from my very first day in office: delivering results for Texans across my district.\"\n\nDespite the raid, Cuellar narrowly defeated a progressive challenger, Jessica Cisneros, in his 2022 primary and went on to win re-election to his seat that November. He didn't face a primary challenger this year and will be on the ballot this November seeking his 11th term in Congress.\n\nTwo years ago, Cuellar easily defeated Republican nominee Cassy Garcia, 57% to 43%. His district became bluer when he picked up parts of San Antonio following redistricting. But the indictment will make Cuellar more vulnerable than in the past; in 2020, Joe Biden won Cuellar's district over Donald Trump by 7 percentage points.\n\nTwo Republicans will face each other in a runoff election in late May for a chance to take on Cuellar in the fall.\n\n\"Henry Cuellar does not put Texas first, he puts himself first,\" said Delanie Bomar, a spokesperson for the National Republican Congressional Committee. \"If his colleagues truly believe in putting 'people over politics,' they will call on him to resign. If not -- they are hypocrites whose statements about public service aren't worth the paper they're written on.\"\n\nCuellar, 66, a lawyer, is a former customs broker and Texas secretary of state. A member of the centrist Blue Dogs and New Democrat Coalition, Cuellar was elected to the House in 2004.\n\nHe's the only Democrat left in Congress who opposes abortion rights -- a position that has infuriated many in his party.", "source": {"uri": "aol.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Aol"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Henry_Cuellar", "type": "person", Cuellar, wife indicted over ties to Azerbaijan", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- Democratic U.S. Rep. Henry Cuellar of Texas and his wife were indicted on conspiracy and bribery charges Friday in connection with a U.S. Department of Justice probe into ties between American business leaders and the former Soviet republic of Azerbaijan.\n\nFrom 2014 to 2021, Cuellar and his wife accepted nearly $600,000 in bribes from an Azerbaijan-controlled energy company and a bank in Mexico, and in exchange, Cuellar agreed to advance the interests of the country and the bank in the U.S., according to the indictments.\n\nAmong other things, Cuellar agreed to influence legislation favorable to Azerbaijan and deliver a pro-Azerbaijan speech on the floor of the U.S. House, the indictment states.\n\nThe longtime congressman released a statement Friday saying he and his wife, Imelda Cuellar, \"are innocent of these allegations.\"\n\n\"Everything I have done in Congress has been to serve the people of South Texas,\" Cuellar said. \"Before I took action, I proactively sought legal advice from the House Ethics Committee, who gave me more than one written opinion, along with an additional opinion from a national law firm.\n\n\"Furthermore, we requested a meeting with the Washington D.C. prosecutors to explain the facts and they refused to discuss the case with us or hear our side.\"\n\nNeither Cuellar nor his attorney immediately responded to calls seeking comment on the matter. Officials with the U.S. Department of Justice declined to discuss the matter.\n\nCuellar was at one time the co-chair of the Congressional Azerbaijan Caucus.\n\nThe FBI searched the congressman's house in the border city of Laredo in 2022, and Cuellar's attorney at that time said Cuellar was not the target of that investigation. That search was part of a broader investigation related to Azerbaijan that saw FBI agents serve a raft of subpoenas and conduct interviews in Washington, D.C., and Texas, a person with direct knowledge of the probe previously told The Associated Press. The person was not authorized to discuss it publicly and spoke on condition of anonymity.\n\nFederal disclosures show that the nine-term congressman traveled to Azerbaijan in 2013. Two years later, Cuellar's office announced an agreement between a Texas university and an organization called the Assembly of Friends of Azerbaijan for the purposes of collaborating on oil and gas research and education.\n\nCuellar, one of the last anti-abortion Democrats in Congress, narrowly defeated progressive challenger Jessica Cisneros by fewer than 300 votes in a primary race in 2022.e challenger Jessica Cisneros in a primary race in 2022 by fewer than 300 votes.", "source": {"uri": "woodtv.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "WOODTV.com"}, "authors": [{"uri": Henry Cuellar of Texas and his wife are indicted over ties to Azerbaijan", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- Democratic U.S. Rep. Henry Cuellar of Texas and his wife were indicted on conspiracy and bribery charges Friday in connection with a U.S. Department of Justice probe into ties between American business leaders and the former Soviet republic of Azerbaijan.\n\nFrom 2014 to 2021, Cuellar and his wife accepted nearly $600,000 in bribes from an Azerbaijan-controlled energy company and a bank in Mexico, and in exchange, Cuellar agreed to advance the interests of the country and the bank in the U.S., according to the indictments.\n\nAmong other things, Cuellar agreed to influence legislation favorable to Azerbaijan and deliver a pro-Azerbaijan speech on the floor of the U.S. House, the indictment states.\n\nThe longtime congressman released a statement Friday saying he and his wife, Imelda Cuellar, \"are innocent of these allegations.\"\n\n\"Everything I have done in Congress has been to serve the people of South Texas,\" Cuellar said. \"Before I took action, I proactively sought legal advice from the House Ethics Committee, who gave me more than one written opinion, along with an additional opinion from a national law firm.\n\n\"Furthermore, we requested a meeting with the Washington D.C. prosecutors to explain the facts and they refused to discuss the case with us or hear our side.\"\n\nNeither Cuellar nor his attorney immediately responded to calls seeking comment on the matter. Officials with the U.S. Department of Justice declined to discuss the matter.\n\nCuellar was at one time the co-chair of the Congressional Azerbaijan Caucus.\n\nThe FBI searched the congressman's house in the border city of Laredo in 2022, and Cuellar's attorney at that time said Cuellar was not the target of that investigation. That search was part of a broader investigation related to Azerbaijan that saw FBI agents serve a raft of subpoenas and conduct interviews in Washington, D.C., and Texas, a person with direct knowledge of the probe previously told The Associated Press. The person was not authorized to discuss it publicly and spoke on condition of anonymity.\n\nFederal disclosures show that the nine-term congressman traveled to Azerbaijan in 2013. Two years later, Cuellar's office announced an agreement between a Texas university and an organization called the Assembly of Friends of Azerbaijan for the purposes of collaborating on oil and gas research and education.\n\nCuellar, one of the last anti-abortion Democrats in Congress, narrowly defeated progressive challenger Jessica Cisneros by fewer than 300 votes in a primary race in 2022.e {"uri": "8109855324", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-03", "time": "14:59:06", "dateTime": "2024-05-03T14:59:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-03T14:58:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8823529481887817, "url": "https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/congress/doj-expected-announce-indictment-texas-democratic-rep-henry-cuellar-so-rcna150567", "title": "DOJ expected to announce indictment of Texas Democratic Rep. Henry Cuellar, sources say", "body": "WASHINGTON -- The Justice Department is expected to announce the indictment of longtime Rep. Henry Cuellar, D-Texas, on Friday, two sources familiar with the matter told NBC News.\n\nCuellar's home and campaign office in Laredo, Texas, were raided in January 2022 as part of a federal investigation into Azerbaijan and a group of U.S. businessmen who have ties to the country, law enforcement said at the time. His office had pledged to cooperate with the investigation. In April, Cuellar's lawyer, Joshua Berman, told some news outlets that federal authorities informed him he was not the target of the investigation.\n\nIt wasn't immediately clear if the indictment was related to the 2022 raid. The Justice Department declined to comment. NBC News has reached out to Cuellar and a lawyer representing him for comment.\n\nCuellar is a one-time co-chair of the Congressional Azerbaijan Caucus.\n\nA year after the raid -- which had not previously yielded arrests or charges -- Cuellar told the Texas Tribune: \"There has been no wrongdoing on my part. ... My focus remains the same from my very first day in office: delivering results for Texans across my district.\"\n\nDespite the raid, Cuellar narrowly defeated a progressive challenger, Jessica Cisneros, in his 2022 primary and went on to win re-election to his seat that November. He didn't face a primary challenger this year and will be on the ballot this November seeking his 11th term in Congress.\n\nTwo years ago, Cuellar easily defeated Republican nominee Cassy Garcia 57% to 43%. His district became bluer when he picked up parts of San Antonio following redistricting. But the indictment will make Cuellar more vulnerable than he has been in the past. Two Republicans will face each other in a runoff election in late May for a chance to take on Cuellar in the fall.\n\nCuellar, 66, a lawyer, is a former customs broker and Texas secretary of state. A member of the centrist Blue Dogs and New Democrat Coalition, Cuellar was first elected to the House in 2004.\n\nHe's the only Democrat left in Congress who opposes abortion rights -- a position that has infuriated many in his party.", "source": {"uri": "nbcnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "NBC News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Henry_Cuellar", "type": {"uri": "8110182127", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-03", "time": "19:30:35", "dateTime": "2024-05-03T19:30:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-03T19:30:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8823529481887817, "url": "https://ktbb.com/post/?p=1319245", "title": "Democratic US Rep. Henry Cuellar of Texas and his wife are indicted over ties to Azerbaijan", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- Democratic U.S. Rep. Henry Cuellar of Texas and his wife were indicted on conspiracy and bribery charges and taken into custody Friday in connection with a U.S. Department of Justice probe into the couple's ties to the former Soviet republic of Azerbaijan.\n\nFrom 2014 to 2021, Cuellar, 68, and his wife accepted nearly $600,000 in bribes from an Azerbaijan-controlled energy company and a bank in Mexico, and in exchange, Cuellar agreed to advance the interests of the country and the bank in the U.S., according to the indictment.\n\nAmong other things, Cuellar agreed to influence legislation favorable to Azerbaijan and deliver a pro-Azerbaijan speech on the floor of the U.S. House, the indictment states.\n\nThe Department of Justice said the couple surrendered to authorities on Friday and were taken into custody. They made an initial appearance before a federal judge in Houston and were each released on $100,000 bond, the DOJ said.\n\nThe longtime congressman released a statement Friday saying he and his wife, Imelda Cuellar, 67, \"are innocent of these allegations.\"\n\n\"Everything I have done in Congress has been to serve the people of South Texas,\" Cuellar said. \"Before I took action, I proactively sought legal advice from the House Ethics Committee, who gave me more than one written opinion, along with an additional opinion from a national law firm.\n\n\"Furthermore, we requested a meeting with the Washington D.C. prosecutors to explain the facts and they refused to discuss the case with us or hear our side.\"\n\nNeither Cuellar nor his attorney immediately responded to calls seeking comment on the matter.\n\nIn addition to bribery and conspiracy, the couple face charges including wire fraud conspiracy, acting as agents of foreign principals and money laundering. If convicted, they face up to decades in prison and forfeiture of any property linked to proceeds from the alleged scheme.\n\nThe payments to the couple initially went through a Texas-based shell company owned by Imelda Cuellar and two of the couple's children, according to the indictment. That company received payments from the Azerbaijan energy company of $25,000 per month under a \"sham contract,\" purportedly in exchange for unspecified strategic consulting and advising services.\n\n\"In reality, the contract was a sham used to disguise and legitimate the corrupt agreement between Henry Cuellar and the government of Azerbaijan,\" the indictment states.\n\nImelda Cuellar sent a falsified invoice to the Azerbaijan energy company's Washington, D.C., office under the agreement, stating her work was complete.\n\n\"In fact, Imelda Cuellar had performed little or no legitimate work under the contract,\" the indictment says.\n\nThe indictment also alleges an Azerbaijani diplomat referred to Henry Cuellar in text messages as \"el Jefe\" or \"boss,\" and also that a member of Cuellar's staff sent multiple emails to officials at the Department of State pressuring them to renew a U.S. passport for an Azerbaijani diplomat's daughter.\n\nCuellar was at one time the co-chair of the Congressional Azerbaijan Caucus.\n\nThe FBI searched the congressman's house in the border city of Laredo in 2022, and Cuellar's attorney at that time said Cuellar was not the target of that investigation. That search was part of a broader investigation related to Azerbaijan that saw FBI agents serve a raft of subpoenas and conduct interviews in Washington, D.C., and Texas, a person with direct knowledge of the probe previously told The Associated Press. The person was not authorized to discuss it publicly and spoke on condition of anonymity.\n\nCuellar, one of the last anti-abortion Democrats in Congress, narrowly defeated progressive challenger Jessica Cisneros by fewer than 300 votes in a primary race in 2022.", "source": {"uri": "ktbb.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "KTBB"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8110199065", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-03", "time": "19:51:39", "dateTime": "2024-05-03T19:51:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-03T19:47:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8784313797950745, "url": "https://www.eagletribune.com/region/texas-democratic-sen-henry-cuellar-indicted-on-federal-bribery-charges/article_b11061d2-465f-56ec-9dcb-5eb17b524945.html", "title": "Texas Democratic Sen. Henry Cuellar indicted on federal bribery charges", "body": "Joseph Morton and Philip Jankowski - The Dallas Morning News (TNS)\n\nWASHINGTON - Federal authorities on Friday indicted U.S. Rep Henry Cuellar of Texas and his wife on allegations they received almost $600,000 in bribes to advance the interests of the former Soviet republic of Azerbaijan.\n\nThe Laredo Democrat and his wife, Imelda Cuellar, were accused in 14 federal charges of participating in two schemes involving bribery, illegal foreign influence and money laundering, the Justice Department said.\n\nThe most serious charges carry a maximum penalty of 20 years in federal prison.\n\nAccording to the Justice Department, the Cuellars accepted bribes from an Azerbaijani oil company and a bank based in Mexico City that is controlled by the government of Azerbaijan. In exchange, Cuellar agreed to work to further the interests of the Eastern European country, agency officials said.\n\nThe Cuellars made their first appearance in a Houston courtroom Friday and were taken into custody, The Associated Press reported.\n\nBefore the indictments became public, Cuellar issued a statement saying he and his wife were innocent and he still plans to seek reelection in November.\n\n\"Everything I have done in Congress has been to serve the people of South Texas,\" he said.\n\nAccording to the Justice Department, the government of Azerbaijan paid Cuellar and his wife through \"sham contracts\" laundered through a series of shell companies owned by Imelda Cuellar, who did little to no work for the money.\n\nIn exchange, the Justice Department said, Henry Cuellar allegedly used his office to influence U.S. foreign policy in Azerbaijan's favor. In exchange for money from the Mexican bank, Cuellar allegedly agreed to \"advise and pressure\" high-ranking U.S. officials to take steps favorable to the bank, the agency said.\n\nThe FBI raided Cuellar's home and campaign office in Laredo on Jan. 19, 2022, although he was not identified as a target of an investigation. ABC News reported the raid was tied to \"a wide-ranging federal probe relating to the former Soviet state of Azerbaijan and several U.S. businessmen.\"\n\nCuellar has been co-chair of the Congressional Azerbaijan Caucus.\n\nSix weeks after the raid, Cuellar fell short of winning his primary by about 700 votes, although he won the runoff.\n\nCuellar said in his statement that he had sought advice from the House Ethics Committee and a national law firm before taking actions described in the indictments.\n\n\"The actions I took in Congress were consistent with the actions of many of my colleagues and in the interest of the American people,\" he said.\n\nCuellar said he had requested a meeting with prosecutors, but they refused to discuss the case or hear his side of the story.\n\n\"Imelda and I have been married for 32 years. On top of being an amazing wife and mother, she's an accomplished businesswoman with two degrees. She spent her career working with banking, tax, and consulting,\" Cuellar said. \"The allegation that she is anything but qualified and hard working is both wrong and offensive.\"\n\nCuellar, who has been in Congress since 2005, is a senior member of the House Appropriations Committee.\n\nU.S. Rep. Hakeem Jeffries, House minority leader, said in a statement that rules require Cuellar to take leave as ranking member of the Homeland Security Appropriations Subcommittee while the charges are pending.\n\n\"Like any American, Congressman Cuellar is entitled to his day in court and the presumption of innocence throughout the legal process,\" Jeffries said.\n\nThe National Republican Congressional Committee called on Cuellar's Democratic colleagues to pressure him to resign.\n\n\"If not - they are hypocrites whose statements about public service aren't worth the paper they're written on,\" committee spokeswoman Delanie Bomar said in a statement.\n\nCuellar represents a south Texas swing district that has helped determine which party controls the U.S. House.\n\nHe is among the most moderate Democrats in the House, breaking with his party at times on issues such as border security and abortion rights. Those positions have drawn the fire of progressives who have tried unsuccessfully to dislodge him with primary challenges.\n\n\u00a92024 The Dallas Morning News. {"uri": "8110660346", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-04", "time": "05:44:58", "dateTime": "2024-05-04T05:44:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-04T05:40:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8784313797950745, "url": "https://exbulletin.com/world/2684493/", "title": "Rep. of Texas Henry Cuellar and his wife are indicted on bribery and foreign influence charges - ExBulletin", "body": "WASHINGTON Justice Department on Friday issued an indictment against Rep. Henry Cuellar, D-Texas, and his wife, Imelda, charging the couple with bribery and money laundering in connection with their ties to a bank in Mexico and an oil and gas company controlled by Azerbaijan.\n\nNBC News was the first to report that the charges were coming. The congressman and his wife were each released on $100,000 bond after their initial appearance in federal court in Houston, a DOJ spokesman said Friday afternoon.\n\nAccording to the indictment, from 2014 to 2021, the Cuellars allegedly accepted approximately $600,000 in bribes from the two foreign entities in exchange for the congressman performing official acts.\n\nThe bribe payments were allegedly laundered, pursuant to bogus consulting contracts, through a series of front companies and middlemen in shell companies owned by Imelda Cuellar, who performed little or no legitimate work under the contracts, the DOJ said in a statement.\n\nIn exchange for bribes paid by the Azerbaijan oil and gas company, Congressman Cuellar allegedly agreed to use his office to influence US foreign policy in favor of Azerbaijan,\" the DOJ continued. \"In exchange for the bribes paid by the Mexican bank, Congressman Cuellar. allegedly agreed to influence legislative activity and to advise and pressure senior US Executive Branch officials on measures beneficial to the bank.\n\nThe congressman and his wife are each charged with two counts of conspiracy to commit bribery of a federal official and to have a public official act as an agent of a foreign principal; two counts of bribery of a federal official; two counts of conspiracy to commit wire fraud; two counts of violating the prohibition on public officials acting as agents of a foreign directorate; one count of conspiracy to commit money laundering; and five counts of money laundering.\n\nIf convicted, they could spend years or even decades in prison.\n\nIn a statement Friday before the charges were unsealed, Cuellar denied any wrongdoing, saying he had proactively sought legal advice from the House Ethics Committee, which had issued more than one written opinion on the matter. . Much of his statement focused on his wife.\n\nI want to be clear that both my wife and I are innocent of these charges. Everything I have done in Congress has been to serve the people of South Texas, Cuellar said in his statement, later adding: The actions I took in Congress were consistent with the actions of many of my colleagues and in the best interest of the american people.\n\nImelda and I have been married for 32 years. In addition to being a wonderful wife and mother, she is an accomplished businesswoman with two degrees. She spent her career working in banking, tax and consulting, he continued. Claiming that she is anything but qualified and hard-working is both wrong and insulting.\n\nA defiant Cuellar also made it clear that he will still seek re-election: Let me be clear, I am running for re-election and I will win this November.\n\nA statement from the congressman's defense attorneys was similar to Cuellar's, but also pointed out that prosecutors indicted him just six months before Election Day.\n\n\"The governments decision to press ahead with the allegations so close to the general election and their decision to execute a search warrant 40 days before it. [2022] primary undermines the electorate and puts a finger on the scale,\" said attorneys Chris Flood and Eric Reed.\n\nHouse Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries, D-N.Y., and other top Democratic leaders had endorsed Cuellar's re-election bid last summer. In a statement, Jeffries spokeswoman Christie Stephenson called Cuellar a \"valued member of the House Democratic Caucus,\" noting that Cuellar is \"entitled to his day in court and the presumption of innocence throughout the process legal\".\n\nMeanwhile, Cuellar will step down from his position as the top Democrat on the House Appropriations subcommittee that oversees the Department of Homeland Security, Stephenson said.\n\nCuellars' home and campaign office in Laredo, Texas, were raided in January 2022 as part of a federal investigation into Azerbaijan and a group of American businessmen with ties to the country, law enforcement said at the time. His office had pledged to cooperate with the investigation. In April, Cuellar's attorney, Joshua Berman,said some mediathat federal authorities informed him that he was not the target of the investigation.\n\nCuellar is a one-time co-chair of the Azerbaijan Congressional Caucus. According to the indictment, in exchange for bribes, Cuellar promised to influence legislation related to Azerbaijan's conflict with neighboring Armenia; inserting pro-Azerbaijani language into legislation and committee reports on security and economic assistance programs; deliver a pro-Azerbaijan speech on the floor of the House of Representatives; and to \"consult\" with Azerbaijani officials regarding their efforts to lobby the US government.\n\nBefore the indictment was issued, Cuellars' staff was calling other members' offices Friday to ask for advice on how to handle the situation, a source with knowledge of those calls told NBC News.\n\nA year after the raid on his home, which has previously resulted in no arrests or charges, Cuellar told the Texas Tribune: There was no wrongdoing on my part. ... My focus remains the same since my first day in office: delivering results for Texans across my district.\n\nDespite the raid, Cuellar narrowly defeated a progressive challenger, Jessica Cisneros, in his 2022 primary and went on to win re-election in his seat that November. He did not face a primary challenger this year and will be on the ballot this November seeking his 11th term in Congress.\n\nTwo years ago, Cuellar easily defeated Republican candidate Cassy Garcia, 57% to 43%. His district became bluer when he took over parts of San Antonio after redistricting. But the indictment will make Cuellar more vulnerable than in the past; in 2020, Joe Biden won Cuellar's district over Donald Trump by 7 percentage points.\n\nTwo Republicans will face each other in a runoff election in late May for a chance to take on Cuellar in the fall.\n\nHenry Cuellar doesn't put Texas first, he puts himself first,\" said Delanie Bomar, a spokeswoman for the Republican National Congressional Committee. \"If his colleagues really believe in putting people over politics, they will call on him to resign. If not, they are hypocrites whose public service announcements are not worth the paper they are written on.\n\nCuellar is facing a call to resign from a member of his own party, Rep. Dean Phillips, D-Minn., who said in a post to X on Friday night that \"while the bar for the federal lawsuit is high, confidence in our government is low.\"\n\n\"This is why incumbents and candidates under indictment must resign or end their campaigns, including Sen. Bob Menendez, Donald Trump and Rep. Henry Cuellar,\" continued Phillips, who was among the first that called on Menendez to resign.\n\nCuellar, 66, an attorney, is a former Texas customs broker and secretary of state. A member of the centrist Blue Dogs and New Democrat coalition, Cuellar was elected to the House of Representatives in 2004.\n\nHe is the only Democrat left in Congress who opposes abortion rights, a position that has angered many in his party.\n\nThe Cuellars are the second congressional couple to be indicted in a foreign bribery scheme in the past year. In September, the DOJ indicted then-Senate Foreign Relations Chairman Bob Menendez, DN.J., and his wife for allegedly accepting hundreds of thousands of dollars, including gold bullion, in exchange for official acts intended to enrich three businessmen of New Jersey and benefit. the Egyptian government. Both Cuellar and Menendez are members of the Congressional Hispanic Caucus.\n\nMenendez, who resigned as director of Foreign Relations, has pleaded not guilty. His trial is scheduled to begin later this month.\n\nA third lawmaker, New York Republican George Santos, was expelled from the House in December after a scathing ethics report and a 23-count federal indictment charging him with crimes such as wire fraud and money laundering. . Santos has also pleaded not guilty.\n\nCORRECTION (May 3, 2024, 4:59 pm ET): Due to an editing error, an earlier version of this article misattributed a statement. {"uri": "8110085350", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-03", "time": "18:00:06", "dateTime": "2024-05-03T18:00:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-03T17:59:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8745098114013672, "url": "https://www.delcotimes.com/2024/05/03/democratic-us-rep-henry-cuellar-of-texas-and-his-wife-are-indicted-over-ties-to-azerbaijan/", "title": "Democratic US Rep. Henry Cuellar of Texas and his wife are indicted over ties to Azerbaijan", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- Democratic U.S. Rep. Henry Cuellar of Texas and his wife were indicted on conspiracy and bribery charges Friday in connection with a U.S. Department of Justice probe into ties between American business leaders and the former Soviet republic of Azerbaijan.\n\nFrom 2014 to 2021, Cuellar and his wife accepted nearly $600,000 in bribes from an Azerbaijan-controlled energy company and a bank in Mexico, and in exchange, Cuellar agreed to advance the interests of the country and the bank in the U.S., according to the indictments.\n\nAmong other things, Cuellar agreed to influence legislation favorable to Azerbaijan and deliver a pro-Azerbaijan speech on the floor of the U.S. House, the indictment states.\n\nThe longtime congressman released a statement Friday saying he and his wife, Imelda Cuellar, \"are innocent of these allegations.\"\n\n\"Everything I have done in Congress has been to serve the people of South Texas,\" Cuellar said. \"Before I took action, I proactively sought legal advice from the House Ethics Committee, who gave me more than one written opinion, along with an additional opinion from a national law firm.\n\n\"Furthermore, we requested a meeting with the Washington D.C. prosecutors to explain the facts and they refused to discuss the case with us or hear our side.\"\n\nNeither Cuellar nor his attorney immediately responded to calls seeking comment on the matter. Officials with the U.S. Department of Justice declined to discuss the matter.\n\nCuellar was at one time the co-chair of the Congressional Azerbaijan Caucus.\n\nThe FBI searched the congressman's house in the border city of Laredo in 2022, and Cuellar's attorney at that time said Cuellar was not the target of that investigation. That search was part of a broader investigation related to Azerbaijan that saw FBI agents serve a raft of subpoenas and conduct interviews in Washington, D.C., and Texas, a person with direct knowledge of the probe previously told The Associated Press. The person was not authorized to discuss it publicly and spoke on condition of anonymity.\n\nFederal disclosures show that the nine-term congressman traveled to Azerbaijan in 2013. Two years later, Cuellar's office announced an agreement between a Texas university and an organization called the Assembly of Friends of Azerbaijan for the purposes of collaborating on oil and gas {"uri": "2024-05-344286765", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-03", "time": "18:02:18", "dateTime": "2024-05-03T18:02:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-03T18:01:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8705882430076599, "url": "https://www.wbaltv.com/article/henry-cuellar-wife-indicted-conspiracy-azerbaijan-texas/60685456", "title": "Democratic US Rep. Henry Cuellar of Texas and his wife indicted over ties to Azerbaijan", "body": "Democratic U.S. Rep. Henry Cuellar of Texas and his wife were indicted on conspiracy and bribery charges Friday in connection with a U.S. Department of Justice probe into ties between American business leaders and the former Soviet republic of Azerbaijan.From 2014 to 2021, Cuellar and his wife accepted nearly $600,000 in bribes from an Azerbaijan-controlled energy company and a bank in Mexico, and in exchange, Cuellar agreed to advance the interests of the country and the bank in the U.S., according to the indictments.Among other things, Cuellar agreed to influence legislation favorable to Azerbaijan and deliver a pro-Azerbaijan speech on the floor of the U.S. House, the indictment states.The longtime congressman released a statement Friday saying he and his wife, Imelda Cuellar, \"are innocent of these allegations.\"\"Everything I have done in Congress has been to serve the people of South Texas,\" Cuellar said. \"Before I took action, I proactively sought legal advice from the House Ethics Committee, who gave me more than one written opinion, along with an additional opinion from a national law firm.\"Furthermore, we requested a meeting with the Washington D.C. prosecutors to explain the facts and they refused to discuss the case with us or hear our side.\"Neither Cuellar nor his attorney immediately responded to calls seeking comment on the matter. Officials with the U.S. Department of Justice declined to discuss the matter.Cuellar was at one time the co-chair of the Congressional Azerbaijan Caucus.The FBI searched the congressman's house in the border city of Laredo in 2022, and Cuellar's attorney at that time said Cuellar was not the target of that investigation. That search was part of a broader investigation related to Azerbaijan that saw FBI agents serve a raft of subpoenas and conduct interviews in Washington, D.C., and Texas, a person with direct knowledge of the probe previously told The Associated Press. The person was not authorized to discuss it publicly and spoke on condition of anonymity.Federal disclosures show that the nine-term congressman traveled to Azerbaijan in 2013. Two years later, Cuellar's office announced an agreement between a Texas university and an organization called the Assembly of Friends of Azerbaijan for the purposes of collaborating on oil and gas research and education.Cuellar, one of the last anti-abortion Democrats in Congress, narrowly defeated progressive challenger Jessica Cisneros by fewer than 300 votes in a primary race in 2022.e challenger Jessica Cisneros in a primary race in 2022 by fewer than 300 votes.\n\nDemocratic U.S. Rep. Henry Cuellar of Texas and his wife were indicted on conspiracy and bribery charges Friday in connection with a U.S. Department of Justice probe into ties between American business leaders and the former Soviet republic of Azerbaijan.\n\nFrom 2014 to 2021, Cuellar and his wife accepted nearly $600,000 in bribes from an Azerbaijan-controlled energy company and a bank in Mexico, and in exchange, Cuellar agreed to advance the interests of the country and the bank in the U.S., according to the indictments.\n\nAmong other things, Cuellar agreed to influence legislation favorable to Azerbaijan and deliver a pro-Azerbaijan speech on the floor of the U.S. House, the indictment states.\n\nThe longtime congressman released a statement Friday saying he and his wife, Imelda Cuellar, \"are innocent of these allegations.\"\n\n\"Everything I have done in Congress has been to serve the people of South Texas,\" Cuellar said. \"Before I took action, I proactively sought legal advice from the House Ethics Committee, who gave me more than one written opinion, along with an additional opinion from a national law firm.\n\n\"Furthermore, we requested a meeting with the Washington D.C. prosecutors to explain the facts and they refused to discuss the case with us or hear our side.\"\n\nNeither Cuellar nor his attorney immediately responded to calls seeking comment on the matter. Officials with the U.S. Department of Justice declined to discuss the matter.\n\nCuellar was at one time the co-chair of the Congressional Azerbaijan Caucus.\n\nThe FBI searched the congressman's house in the border city of Laredo in 2022, and Cuellar's attorney at that time said Cuellar was not the target of that investigation. That search was part of a broader investigation related to Azerbaijan that saw FBI agents serve a raft of subpoenas and conduct interviews in Washington, D.C., and Texas, a person with direct knowledge of the probe previously told The Associated Press. The person was not authorized to discuss it publicly and spoke on condition of anonymity.\n\nFederal disclosures show that the nine-term congressman traveled to Azerbaijan in 2013. Two years later, Cuellar's office announced an agreement between a Texas university and an organization called the Assembly of Friends of Azerbaijan for the purposes of collaborating on oil and gas research and education.\n\nCuellar, one of the last anti-abortion Democrats in Congress, narrowly defeated progressive challenger Jessica Cisneros by fewer than 300 votes in a primary race in 2022.e {"uri": "8109961608", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-03", "time": "16:17:37", "dateTime": "2024-05-03T16:17:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-03T16:16:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8705882430076599, "url": "https://townhall.com/tipsheet/spencerbrown/2024/05/03/democrat-member-of-congress-indictment-looms-n2638602", "title": "Democrat Congressman Insists He'll Win Re-Election Ahead of Expected DOJ Indictment", "body": "Democrat U.S. Representative Henry Cuellar (TX) is expected to be indicted on federal charges announced by the Department of Justice on Friday according to sources reported by multiple outlets.\n\nNBC News noted on Friday morning that while the nature of the indictment remains unknown, Cuellar -- who was first elected to Congress in 2004 -- had his residence and campaign office raided by the FBI in early 2022 amid a federal probe of American businessmen with ties to Azerbaijan. Cuellar previously co-chaired the Congressional Azerbaijan Caucus and was said to be cooperating with the FBI's investigation more than two years ago. His office later claimed that Cuellar was not the target of that investigation.\n\nIn a statement released by his campaign Friday morning, Cuellar declared that he and his wife \"are innocent of these allegations\" and said \"everything\" he's done in Congress \"has been to serve the people of South Texas.\"\n\n\"These allegations have been difficult on my family,\" Cuellar lamented. \"But, with your prayers, we will overcome.\" Despite the looming indictment from Biden's DOJ, a defiant Cuellar said he is still \"running for re-election and will win this November.\"\n\nMore from Cuellar's statement that came out as reports broke the imminently looming indictment:\n\nImelda and I have been married for 32 years. On top of being an amazing wife and mother, she's an accomplished businesswoman with two degrees. She spent her career working with banking, tax, and consulting. The allegation that she is anything but qualified and hard working is both wrong and offensive.\n\nAs the son of migrant workers, I was taught to wake up early and work hard. That's exactly what I've always done for the people of South Texas. I've devoted my life's work to creating jobs here, improving education, and securing our border.\n\nCuellar added in his statement that he \"proactively sought legal advice from the House Ethics Committee\" and obtained \"an additional opinion from a national law firm\" related to the matter, but an attempt to get a meeting with the Justice Department \"to explain the facts\" did not happen. \"[T]hey refused to discuss the case with us or to hear our side,\" Cuellar said.\n\nAccording to the NBC News report, Cuellar's aides were \"calling other member offices Friday seeking advice on how to handle the situation.\"", "source": {"uri": "townhall.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Townhall"}, "authors": [{"uri": "spencer_brown@townhall.com", "name": "Spencer Brown", "type": "author", {"uri": "2024-05-344491254", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-03", "time": "23:59:29", "dateTime": "2024-05-03T23:59:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-03T22:27:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8705882430076599, "url": "https://www.eagletribune.com/region/democratic-rep-henry-cuellar-and-wife-indicted-on-bribery-schemes/article_9e73b499-c26c-53f9-932f-d379686d2303.html", "title": "Democratic Rep. Henry Cuellar and wife indicted on bribery schemes", "body": "WASHINGTON -- Rep. Henry Cuellar and his wife have been indicted in two schemes involving unlawful foreign influence, bribery and money laundering, the Justice Department announced Friday.\n\nAn indictment unsealed Friday in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Texas accused the Texas Democrat and his wife, Imelda Cuellar, of taking about $600,000 in bribes from the government of Azerbaijan and an unnamed foreign bank headquartered in Mexico City.\n\n\"The bribe payments were allegedly laundered, pursuant to sham consulting contracts, through a series of front companies and middlemen into shell companies owned by Imelda Cuellar, who performed little to no legitimate work under the contracts,\" a Justice Department press release said.\n\nCuellar allegedly agreed to use his office to influence U.S. foreign policy in favor of Azerbaijan and agreed to influence legislative activity and to advise and pressure high-ranking U.S. executive branch officials regarding measures beneficial to the Mexican bank, the DOJ said.\n\nCuellar and his wife each face a range of federal criminal charges, including five counts of money laundering, two counts of bribery of a federal official and two counts of conspiracy to commit honest services wire fraud, according to the Justice Department.\n\nCuellar and his wife made their initial court appearance on Friday before a U.S. magistrate judge in Texas, the Justice Department said.\n\nRepresentatives for Cuellar could not be immediately reached for comment Friday.\n\nIn a widely circulated statement, Cuellar asserted his and his wife's innocence and that his actions were consistent with those of his colleagues. Cuellar also argued that his wife, who has a career in business and tax consulting, was qualified to do her work.\n\n\"I want to be clear that both my wife and I are innocent of these allegations. Everything I have done in Congress has been to serve the people of South Texas,\" Cuellar's statement said.\n\nCuellar's statement said he had consulted with the House Ethics Committee about his actions and intended to run for reelection this fall.\n\n\"Let me be clear, I'm running for re-election and will win this November,\" the statement said.\n\nThe indictment comes more than two years after Cuellar's home was reportedly raided by the FBI in connection with a federal investigation related to Azerbaijan.\n\nThe indictment alleged in one scheme that Cuellar and his wife were recruited by the company controlled by the Azerbaijani government shortly after a 2013 trip to Turkey and Azerbaijan.\n\nThe couple then entered multiple sham contracts with the company to receive bribes, the indictment alleged, in exchange for advocating for Azerbaijani interests in Congress.\n\n\"Pursuant to these corrupt agreements, HENRY CUELLAR promised to use the power and prestige of his office to advance Azerbaijan's and Foreign Bank-1's interests in the United States,\" the indictment said.\n\nThat included Cuellar advocating for greater Azerbaijani control of the Nagorno-Karabakh region that borders Armenia, working on immigration issues for an Azerbaijani citizen and promoting Azerbaijan as a U.S. ally, according to the indictment.\n\nOver the years, Cuellar communicated with foreign officials about language in the National Defense Authorization Act, appropriations bills and speeches he planned to give in Congress, and other matters, the indictment states.\n\nCuellar repeatedly referred to an unnamed foreign diplomat as \"Sir\" in text message exchanges included in the indictment. In one such exchange, the unnamed foreign diplomat asked Cuellar to ask an unnamed House member, a member of the Congressional Armenian Caucus, to withdraw an amendment that would pay to remove land mines from the Nagorno-Karabakh region.\n\nIn the second scheme alleged by the indictment, a Mexican bank established a financial relationship between the Cuellar couple and two other unnamed people to facilitate bribe payments starting in 2016.\n\nThe indictment alleged that in exchange for the payments, Cuellar advocated for the bank's interests, including an increase in correspondent bank relationships between banks based in Mexico and America.\n\nCuellar's steps included meetings with high-ranking executive branch officials, consulting with officials at the Mexican bank about banking issues, legislation before Congress, the indictment states.\n\nCuellar, who has served in Congress since 2005, represents a Texas district that stretches from parts of San Antonio to a swath of the southern border with Mexico.\n\nHe is a member of the House Appropriations Committee and is known as one of the more conservative Democrats in the chamber. He's the only remaining Democrat in Congress who opposes abortion rights.\n\nChristie Stephenson, a spokeswoman for House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries, D-N.Y., who previously endorsed Cuellar for reelection, said in a statement Friday that Cuellar has \"devoted his career to public service and is a valued Member of the House Democratic Caucus\" but that Cuellar would leave his post as ranking member of the House Homeland Security Appropriations Subcommittee during the case.\n\n\"Like any American, Congressman Cuellar is entitled to his day in court and the presumption of innocence throughout the legal process,\" Stephenson said.\n\nCuellar beat progressive challenger Jessica Cisneros in a close 2022 primary race. He went on to defeat Republican opponent Cassy Garcia in the general election with a tally of 57 percent to 43 percent of the vote.\n\nTwo Republicans, Jay Furman and Lazaro Garza Jr., will face each other in the GOP runoff later this month to decide who runs for Cuellar's seat in the fall.\n\nIn a video posted on social media in January 2022, Cuellar said there was an ongoing investigation, but said the probe would show there was \"no wrongdoing\" on his part.\n\nWith control of the House determined by a few dozen competitive seats this fall, the fate of Cuellar's seat could decide partisan control of the chamber.\n\n\u00a92024 CQ-Roll Call, Inc., All Rights Reserved. Visit cqrollcall.com. {"uri": "8110108901", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-03", "time": "18:20:45", "dateTime": "2024-05-03T18:20:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-03T18:19:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8666666746139526, "url": "https://www.trentonian.com/2024/05/03/democratic-us-rep-henry-cuellar-of-texas-and-his-wife-are-indicted-over-ties-to-azerbaijan/", "title": "Democratic US Rep. Henry Cuellar of Texas and his wife are indicted over ties to Azerbaijan", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- Democratic U.S. Rep. Henry Cuellar of Texas and his wife were indicted on conspiracy and bribery charges and taken into custody Friday in connection with a U.S. Department of Justice probe into ties between American business leaders and the former Soviet republic of Azerbaijan.\n\nFrom 2014 to 2021, Cuellar and his wife accepted nearly $600,000 in bribes from an Azerbaijan-controlled energy company and a bank in Mexico, and in exchange, Cuellar agreed to advance the interests of the country and the bank in the U.S., according to the indictment.\n\nAmong other things, Cuellar agreed to influence legislation favorable to Azerbaijan and deliver a pro-Azerbaijan speech on the floor of the U.S. House, the indictment states.\n\nThe Department of Justice said the couple surrendered to authorities on Friday and were taken into custody.\n\nThe longtime congressman released a statement Friday saying he and his wife, Imelda Cuellar, \"are innocent of these allegations.\"\n\n\"Everything I have done in Congress has been to serve the people of South Texas,\" Cuellar said. \"Before I took action, I proactively sought legal advice from the House Ethics Committee, who gave me more than one written opinion, along with an additional opinion from a national law firm.\n\n\"Furthermore, we requested a meeting with the Washington D.C. prosecutors to explain the facts and they refused to discuss the case with us or hear our side.\"\n\nNeither Cuellar nor his attorney immediately responded to calls seeking comment on the matter.\n\nThe payments to the couple went through a Texas-based shell company owned by Imelda Cuellar and two of the couple's children, according to the indictment. That company received payments from the Azerbaijan energy company of $25,000 per month under a \"sham contract,\" purportedly in exchange for unspecified strategic consulting and advising services.\n\n\"In reality, the contract was a sham used to disguise and legitimate the corrupt agreement between Henry Cuellar and the government of Azerbaijan,\" the indictment states.\n\nImelda Cuellar sent a falsified invoice to the Azerbaijan energy company's Washington, D.C., office under the agreement, stating her work was complete.\n\n\"In fact, Imedla Cuellar had performed little or no legitimate work under the contract,\" the indictment says.\n\nCuellar was at one time the co-chair of the Congressional Azerbaijan Caucus.\n\nThe FBI searched the congressman's house in the border city of Laredo in 2022, and Cuellar's attorney at that time said Cuellar was not the target of that investigation. That search was part of a broader investigation related to Azerbaijan that saw FBI agents serve a raft of subpoenas and conduct interviews in Washington, D.C., and Texas, a person with direct knowledge of the probe previously told The Associated Press. The person was not authorized to discuss it publicly and spoke on condition of anonymity.\n\nFederal disclosures show that the nine-term congressman traveled to Azerbaijan in 2013. Two years later, Cuellar's office announced an agreement between a Texas university and an organization called the Assembly of Friends of Azerbaijan for the purposes of collaborating on oil and gas {"uri": "8110596903", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-04", "time": "04:30:40", "dateTime": "2024-05-04T04:30:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-04T04:25:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8666666746139526, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/ap/article-13381965/Rep-Henry-Cuellar-Texas-vows-continue-bid-11th-term-despite-bribery-indictment.html", "title": "Rep. Henry Cuellar of Texas vows to continue his bid for an 11th...", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) - For two decades, U.S. Rep. Henry Cuellar has stood out as a moderate Democrat along the Texas-Mexico border, bucking his party at times over guns and immigration while seldom facing a tough reelection.\n\nBut a federal indictment accusing Cuellar of federal conspiracy and bribery charges is putting the Laredo native who was first elected in 2004 in a different spotlight. Cuellar, 68, and his wife, Imelda, 67, were taken into custody Friday in connection with a U.S. Department of Justice probe into the couple's ties to the former Soviet republic of Azerbaijan.\n\nThe congressman professed his innocence after the indictment was revealed and vowed to continue his bid for an 11th term in November, saying, \"Everything I have done in Congress has been to serve the people of South Texas.\"\n\nThe Cuellars are accused of accepting nearly $600,000 in bribes from an Azerbaijan-controlled energy company and a bank in Mexico. In exchange, Cuellar allegedly agreed to advance those entities' interests in the U.S.\n\nThe couple surrendered to authorities, made an initial appearance before a federal judge in Houston and were each released on $100,000 bond, the DOJ said.\n\nCuellar's family is a political fixture along the border: His brother is the sheriff in Laredo, and his sister, a former municipal judge, is also on the ballot this year, running as a Democratic candidate for state representative.\n\nFILE - Rep. Henry Cuellar, D-Texas, speaks during a hearing of the Homeland Security Subcommittee of the House Committee on Appropriations with Homeland Security Secretary Alejandro Mayorkas on Capitol Hill, April 10, 2024, in Washington. In a statement released Friday, May 3, Cuellar denied any wrongdoing amid reports of pending indictments related to the former Soviet republic of Azerbaijan. (AP Photo/Mark Schiefelbein, File)\n\nSeveral of Cuellar's allies in the district, which stretches from the Rio Grande to the San Antonio suburbs, expressed surprise over the indictments but said they would still support his reelection. Cuellar's moderate politics have helped him maintain support in places where Democrats have lost ground, like Starr County, a rural and agricultural part of South Texas.\n\n\"It is extremely surprising for me because I\u00b4ve known Henry for many, many years,\" Starr County Judge Eloy Vera said. \"He\u00b4s always been a very straight guy, you know, very sincere. I mean, he\u00b4s done so much for us in Starr County. I hate to see this going on.\"\n\nPresident Joe Biden won Starr County by a slim, single-digit margin. Two years later, Cuellar won it by 40%.\n\nSylvia Bruni, chair of nearby Webb County\u00b4s Democratic Party, said she would trust the legal system to work fairly and her focus would remain on elections. \"We have a campaign to advance, our Democracy at stake,\" she said in a statement.\n\nCuellar released a statement Friday saying he and his wife \"are innocent of these allegations.\"\n\n\"Before I took action, I proactively sought legal advice from the House Ethics Committee, who gave me more than one written opinion, along with an additional opinion from a national law firm,\" the statement said.\n\n\"Furthermore, we requested a meeting with the Washington D.C. prosecutors to explain the facts and they refused to discuss the case with us or hear our side.\"\n\nIn addition to bribery and conspiracy, the couple face charges including wire fraud conspiracy, acting as agents of foreign principals and money laundering. If convicted, they could be punished with up to decades in prison and forfeiture of any property linked to proceeds from the alleged scheme.\n\nThe payments to the couple initially went through a Texas-based shell company owned by Imelda Cuellar and two of the couple\u00b4s children, according to the indictment. That company received payments from the Azerbaijan energy company of $25,000 per month under a \"sham contract,\" purportedly in exchange for unspecified strategic consulting and advising services.\n\n\"In reality, the contract was a sham used to disguise and legitimate the corrupt agreement between Henry Cuellar and the government of Azerbaijan,\" the indictment says.\n\nImelda Cuellar is alleged to have sent a falsified invoice to the energy company's Washington, D.C., office under the agreement, saying her work was complete.\n\n\"In fact, Imelda Cuellar had performed little or no legitimate work under the contract,\" the indictment says.\n\nThe indictment alleges that an Azerbaijani diplomat referred to Henry Cuellar in text messages as both \"el Jefe\" and \"boss,\" and also that a member of Cuellar\u00b4s staff sent multiple emails to officials at the State Department pressuring them to renew a U.S. passport for an Azerbaijani diplomat\u00b4s daughter.\n\nCuellar was at one time the co-chair of the Congressional Azerbaijan Caucus.\n\nThe FBI searched the congressman\u00b4s house in the border city of Laredo in 2022, and Cuellar\u00b4s attorney at that time said he was not the target of the investigation.\n\nCuellar, one of the last anti-abortion Democrats in Congress, narrowly defeated progressive challenger Jessica Cisneros by fewer than 300 votes in a primary race in 2022. Cuellar has been among his party's loudest critics of Biden, particularly over the administration's response to a record number of migrant crossings on the border. His moderate politics have aligned him at times with Republicans on issues including abortion and guns. ___\n\nGonzalez reported from McAllen, Texas. Sean Murphy contributed from Oklahoma City.\n\nFILE - Federal agents search the home of Rep. Henry Cuellar, D-Texas, in Laredo, Texas, Jan. 19, 2022. Cuellar and his wife were indicted on conspiracy and bribery charges and taken into custody Friday, May 3, 2024, in connection with a U.S. Department of Justice probe into the couple's ties to the former Soviet republic of Azerbaijan. {"uri": "8110432510", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-04", "time": "00:38:43", "dateTime": "2024-05-04T00:38:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-04T00:38:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8627451062202454, "url": "https://www.voanews.com/a/democratic-us-congressman-indicted-over-ties-to-azerbaijan-/7597687.html", "title": "Democratic US congressman indicted over ties to Azerbaijan", "body": "Democratic U.S. Rep. Henry Cuellar of Texas and his wife were indicted on conspiracy and bribery charges and taken into custody Friday in connection with a U.S. Department of Justice probe into the couple's ties to the former Soviet republic of Azerbaijan.\n\nFrom 2014 to 2021, Cuellar, 68, and his wife allegedly accepted nearly $600,000 in bribes from an Azerbaijan-controlled energy company and a bank in Mexico, according to the indictment. In exchange, Cuellar is accused of agreeing to advance the interests of the country and the bank in the U.S., also according to the indictment.\n\nAmong other things, Cuellar agreed to influence legislation favorable to Azerbaijan and deliver a pro-Azerbaijan speech on the floor of the U.S. House, the indictment states.\n\nThe Department of Justice said the couple surrendered to authorities on Friday and were taken into custody. They made an initial appearance before a federal judge in Houston and were each released on $100,000 bond, the DOJ said.\n\nThe longtime congressman released a statement Friday saying he and his wife, Imelda Cuellar, 67, \"are innocent of these allegations.\"\n\nNeither Cuellar nor his attorney immediately responded to calls seeking comment on the matter.\n\nIn addition to bribery and conspiracy, the couple face charges including wire fraud conspiracy, acting as agents of foreign principals and money laundering. If convicted, they face up to decades in prison and forfeiture of any property linked to proceeds from the alleged scheme.\n\nThe payments to the couple initially went through a Texas-based shell company owned by Imelda Cuellar and two of the couple's children, according to the indictment. That company received payments from the Azerbaijan energy company of $25,000 per month under a contract, purportedly in exchange for unspecified strategic consulting and advising services.\n\n\"In reality, the contract was a sham used to disguise and legitimate the corrupt agreement between Henry Cuellar and the government of Azerbaijan,\" the indictment states.\n\nThe indictment also alleges an Azerbaijani diplomat referred to Henry Cuellar in text messages as \"boss\" and also that a member of Cuellar's staff sent multiple emails to officials at the Department of State pressuring them to renew a U.S. passport for an Azerbaijani diplomat's daughter.\n\nCuellar was at one time the co-chair of the Congressional Azerbaijan Caucus.\n\nThe FBI searched the congressman's house in the border city of Laredo in 2022, and Cuellar's attorney at that time said Cuellar was not the target of that investigation. That search was part of a broader investigation related to Azerbaijan that saw FBI agents serve a raft of subpoenas and conduct interviews in Washington and Texas, a person with direct knowledge of the probe previously told The Associated Press.", "source": {"uri": "voanews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "VOA Voice of America"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "https://gdb.voanews.com/6338D422-6B48-46DD-A6DC-EE1F6AE4F1C5.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9537117", "eventUri": "eng-9537117", "location": null, "extractedDates": null,
