{"uri": "8110330702", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-03", "time": "22:15:21", "dateTime": "2024-05-03T22:15:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-03T22:13:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8392156958580017, "url": "https://www.cbsnews.com/colorado/news/henry-cuellar-innocent-justice-department-indictment/", "title": "Democratic Rep. Henry Cuellar and wife indicted on federal bribery charges", "body": "Washington -- Democratic Rep. Henry Cuellar and his wife were indicted on more than a dozen federal charges alleging they took hundreds of thousands of dollars in bribes from an oil company owned by the government of Azerbaijan and a Mexican bank, the Justice Department said Friday.\n\nThe 54-page indictment filed in federal district court in Houston was unsealed Friday and charges Cuellar with 14 counts including conspiracy, bribery, and money laundering. He is also accused of acting as a foreign agent to benefit the government of Azerbaijan.\n\nCuellar and his wife, Imelda Rios Cuellar, made their initial appearance before a federal magistrate judge in Houston, where they both pled not guilty and were released on an unsecured bond. The jury trial has been tentatively scheduled to begin July 8.\n\nFederal prosecutors allege that Cuellar and Imelda Cuellar accepted at least $598,000 in bribes from the Azerbaijani oil and gas company and the bank, which is headquartered in Mexico City. They allege that the bribes were laundered in the form of sham consulting contracts through front companies and middlemen into shell companies owned by Imelda Cuellar. The congressman's wife, according to the indictment, \"performed little or no legitimate\" work under the consulting contracts.\n\nProsecutors said in exchange for the bribes, Cuellar agreed to use the \"power and prestige of his office\" to advance the interests of Azerbaijan and the foreign bank, which was unidentified in the indictment.\n\nNBC News was first to report that the indictment was expected Friday. The congressman indicated in a statement before the charges were made public that he and his wife were facing criminal counts and said they are innocent.\n\nThe congressman said he will continue to seek reelection to the House in November.\n\n\"I want to be clear that both my wife and I are innocent of these allegations. Everything I have done in Congress has been to serve the people of South Texas,\" he said.\n\nThe congressman said in his statement that he had sought legal advice from the House Ethics Committee before taking any action -- though it was not clear from the statement what actions he is referring to. The committee provided a written opinion, as well as a second one from a national law firm, he said. Cuellar and his wife also requested a meeting with prosecutors in Washington, D.C., \"to explain the facts,\" he said, but they declined to discuss the case with them.\n\nA spokesperson for Democratic Leader Hakeem Jeffries said the congressman will take leave as the top Democrat on the Homeland Security Appropriations Subcommittee while the case is ongoing.\n\n\"Henry Cuellar has admirably devoted his career to public service and is a valued Member of the House Democratic Caucus. Like any American, Congressman Cuellar is entitled to his day in court and the presumption of innocence throughout the legal process,\" Christie Stephenson, Jeffries' spokesperson, said in a statement.\n\nThe indictment alleges that the congressman's ties to Azerbaijan began in early 2013, when he and his wife traveled to Istanbul and Baku, Azerbaijan, on a trip sponsored by an organization led by a Houston resident. The unidentified resident leads two nonprofits dedicated to advancing the Azerbaijan's interest, prosecutors said.\n\nThe groups receive funding from the energy company owned by the government of Azerbaijan.\n\nShortly after the trip, according to prosecutors, officials within the Azerbaijani government \"discussed recruiting [Cuellar] to promote Azerbaijan's interests in the United States Congress.\"\n\nOne year later, in February 2014, the Justice Department said the Cuellars negotiated a \"corrupt agreement\" with the government-connected oil company, through which it would make monthly payments to a shell company Imelda Cuellar owns for purported \"strategic consulting and advising services.\"\n\nBy May of that year, after the shell companies had been created, investigators alleged Cuellar took overt steps to benefit the foreign government, telling his contacts he had \"placed language within that year's National Defense Authorization Act\" to \"develop a strategic framework for United States security force assistance and cooperation in the European and Eurasian regions,\" including in Azerbaijan.\n\nThe relationship continued for years, investigators said. According to court documents, in 2017 a diplomat from the country sent the congressman information about a land mine-clearing operation in the region that Azerbaijan opposed.\n\n\"I see it. We work on it,\" Cuellar allegedly responded. \"Thank you Boss,\" the diplomat wrote back, according to court papers.\n\nProsecutors alleged that the congressman's staff also pressured the State Department to renew the U.S. passport of an Azerbaijani diplomat's daughter, and Cuellar suggested he would offer amendments to legislation relating to Azerbaijan.\n\nBut it was not just Azerbaijan. Investigators said Cuellar and his wife allegedly set up shell companies and contracts with the Mexican retail bank in an effort to launder additional funds.\n\nThe bank, according to prosecutors, needed a better reciprocal relationship with U.S. financial institutions to exchange currency. In 2015, Cuellar allegedly agreed to place certain language in House bills to support such transactions.\n\n\"From May to July 2016, [Cuellar] advised and pressured U.S. Official-3, a high-ranking Executive Branch official with responsibility for the supervision of banks, to take official acts benefitting Foreign Bank-1,\" investigators said in court documents.\n\nThe indictment revealed the Cuellars used much of their allegedly illicit proceeds to pay federal and state taxes, and make credit card and car payments. Tens of thousands of dollars were spent at restaurants and stores, prosecutors said, and they paid $12,000 for a \"custom gown,\" $7,000 for a down payment on a new car and $27,000 to insurance and telecom companies.\n\nThe alleged scheme involving Azerbaijan and the Mexican bank comes more than two years after the FBI conducted a \"court-authorized\" search of the congressman's home in Laredo and campaign office in January 2022, though Cuellar's lawyer told CBS News at the time that the congressman was not the target of a federal investigation. A source familiar with the probe said then that the activity at Cuellar's house was part of an investigation related to Azerbaijan and several U.S. businessmen.\n\nThe congressman's office said at the time that he was cooperating fully with the investigation, and Cuellar denied wrongdoing.\n\nCuellar was elected to the House in 2005 and represents the 28th Congressional District. His district stretches from San Antonio south to the U.S.-Mexico border. Considered a moderate Democrat, Cuellar faced a tough primary challenge from immigration attorney Jessica Cisneros, his former intern, during the 2022 election cycle, but narrowly defeated her in a runoff election.\n\nCuellar, who is Catholic, is the only remaining self-identified \"pro-life\" Democrat in the House. He was in the news in October 2023 when he said he was carjacked by three armed assailants while returning to his home in the Navy Yard neighborhood of Washington, D.C.", "source": {"uri": Henry Cuellar, the Texas Democrat indicted by the Justice Department?", "body": "Rep. Henry Cuellar says the Biden administration should listen more and offer more to border communities like his while shaping immigration policy.\n\nThe Justice Department released an indictment against Texas Democrat Rep. Henry Cuellar on criminal charges, multiple media outlets reported on Friday.\n\nCuellar is serving his tenth term in the U.S. House of Representatives for Texas' 28th congressional district, which includes the cities of Laredo, Rio Grande City, and San Antonio.\n\nAccording to a biography, Cuellar was born in Laredo, Texas, where he earned his associate degree from Laredo Community College before enrolling at Georgetown University in Washington, D.C. He later earned several postgraduate degrees in Texas before he began practicing law in 1981. He also served as a Texas State Representative and Texas Secretary of State before becoming a U.S. Congressman.\n\nHe and his wife, Imelda, and two daughters live in Laredo.\n\nWhat is Rep. Cuellar being investigated for?\n\nNBC News was the first to report about the expected indictment, stating that Cuellar and his wife are being charged with bribery and money laundering in connection to an Azerbaijani oil and gas company.\n\nNBC News reported that \"The Cuellars allegedly accepted roughly $600,000 in bribes from the two foreign entities in exchange for the congressman performing official acts.\"\n\nThe FBI executed a search warrant at Cuellar's home and campaign office in 2022 but it is unclear if any potential federal charges are related to the raid. Cuellar serves as a co-chair of the Congressional Azerbaijan Caucus.\n\nHis lawyer Joshua Berman said in April that he was informed by the feds that Cuellar was not the focus of the investigation.\n\nWhat did Rep. Cuellar say about the indictment?\n\n\"I want to be clear that both my wife and I are innocent of these allegations,\" Cuellar said in a statement to USA TODAY, indicating his wife Imelda, is also involved.\n\n\"Proactively sought legal advice from the House Ethics Committee, who gave me more than one written opinion, along with an additional opinion from a national law firm,\" he said. \"Furthermore, we requested a meeting with the Washington D.C. prosecutors to explain the facts and they refused to discuss the case with us or to hear our side.\"\n\nThe National Republican Congressional Committee, the campaign arm of House Republicans, swiftly responded to reports of an imminent criminal indictment and urged House Democrats to call on their colleague to resign.\n\n\"Henry Cuellar does not put Texas first, he puts himself first,\" Delanie Bomar, a spokesperson for the NRCC said in a statement. \"If his colleagues truly believe in putting 'people over politics,' they will call on him to resign. If not - they are hypocrites whose statements about public service aren't worth the paper they're written on.\"", "source": {"uri": "eu.statesman.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "USA TODAY"}, {"uri": "8110471326", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-04", "time": "01:40:34", "dateTime": "2024-05-04T01:40:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-04T01:39:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8392156958580017, "url": "https://wsvn.com/news/politics/rep-henry-cuellar-and-his-wife-allegedly-took-nearly-600000-in-bribes-indictment-says/", "title": "Rep. Henry Cuellar and his wife allegedly took nearly $600,000 in bribes, indictment says - WSVN 7News | Miami News, Weather, Sports | Fort Lauderdale", "body": "(CNN) -- Democratic Rep. Henry Cuellar of Texas and his wife have been charged with accepting nearly $600,000 in bribes from two foreign entities, according to an indictment in federal court in Texas.\n\nThe alleged scheme took place from late 2014 through at least November 2021, the indictment says.\n\nThe congressman and his wife, Imelda Cuellar, made their initial court appearance on Friday in Houston and were released on a $100,000 bond. They are facing several charges, including conspiracy to commit bribery of a federal official, violating the ban on public officials acting as agents of a foreign principal and money laundering.\n\nIn a statement on Friday, Cuellar said: \"I want to be clear that both my wife and I are innocent of these allegations. Everything I have done in Congress has been to serve the people of South Texas.\"\n\nCuellar said in his statement that actions he took in Congress were \"in the interest of the American people\" and vowed to continue his bid for reelection in November. The congressman also defended his wife, saying that, \"The allegation that she is anything but qualified and hard working is both wrong and offensive.\"\n\n\"The actions I took in Congress were consistent with the actions of many of my colleagues and in the interest of the American people,\" Cuellar said.\n\nProsecutors say that Henry and Imelda Cuellar crafted two yearslong schemes to get bribes from foreign entities - an oil and gas company \"wholly owned and controlled by the Government of Azerbaijan, and a bank headquartered in Mexico City.\"\n\nIn exchange for bribe payments from the Azerbaijan oil company, Cuellar \"agreed to perform official acts in his capacity as a Member of Congress, to commit acts in violation of his official duties, and to act as an agent of the Government of Azerbaijan\" and the bank, the indictment says.\n\nAmong those promises, prosecutors allege Cuellar agreed to influence US policy through a \"series of legislative measures relating to Azerbaijan's conflict with neighboring Armenia,\" by giving a pro-Azerbaijani speech on the House floor, inserting language \"favored by Azerbaijan\" into legislation and committee reports, and advocating for \"series of legislative measures relating to Azerbaijan's conflict with neighboring Armenia.\"\n\nThe Texas Democrat also allegedly promised to influence financial regulations in a way that would benefit the Mexican bank and its affiliates, including by working to pressure the Executive Branch on anti-money laundering enforcement practices that \"threatened\" their business interest and supporting revisions to the criminal money-laundering statutes.\n\nThe couple received the bribe payments through shell companies owned by Imelda Cuellar, prosecutors say. They allegedly used the proceeds from the bribery schemes to pay taxes, pay down debt and spend tens of thousands of dollars at restaurants and retail stores. One purchase was for a $12,000 custom gown, according to the indictment.\n\nCuellar's home and campaign office in Laredo, Texas, were raided by the FBI in 2022. The charges against Cuellar are not yet publicly available.\n\nA spokesperson for House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries released a statement shortly after Cuellar's charges were reported, saying that the congressman is entitled to the presumption of innocence. But, spokesperson Christie Stephenson said, Cuellar will temporarily step down from his top spot on a House Appropriations Subcommittee while the investigation is ongoing.\n\n\"Henry Cuellar has admirably devoted his career to public service and is a valued Member of the House Democratic Caucus. Like any American, Congressman Cuellar is entitled to his day in court and the presumption of innocence throughout the legal process,\" Stephenson said.\n\nThe National Republican Congressional Committee swiftly called on Cuellar to resign.\n\n\"If his colleagues truly believe in putting 'people over politics,' they will call on him to resign. If not -- they are hypocrites whose statements about public service aren't worth the paper they're written on,\" Delanie Bomar, a spokesperson for the NRCC, said in a statement.\n\nThe-CNN-Wire\u2122 & \u00a9 2024 Cable News Network, Inc., a Time Warner Company. Henry Cuellar Charged With Accepting Massive Bribes From Azerbaijan", "body": "Rep. Henry Cuellar has been one of the only Democrats in Congress to speak out against Joe Biden's border policies. Now, the Justice Department has charged the congressman and his wife Imelda with accepting $600,000 in bribes, money laundering, and other charges.\n\nThe indictment reveals a good, old-fashioned \"pay for play\" scheme with Cuellar doing various favors for the Azerbaijan government in exchange for cash and looping in a corrupt Mexican bank for a cut.\n\nCuellar \"agreed to perform official acts in his capacity as a Member of Congress, to commit acts in violation of his official duties, and to act as an agent of the Government of Azerbaijan\" and the bank, the indictment says.\n\nCuellar says he's innocent.\n\n\"Everything I have done in Congress has been to serve the people of South Texas,\" Cuellar said. \"Before I took action, I proactively sought legal advice from the House Ethics Committee, who gave me more than one written opinion, along with an additional opinion from a national law firm.\"\n\nThat may be. But he sure didn't act like the actions he took on behalf of Azerbaijan were on the up and up.\n\nThe couple received payments from Azerbaijan through a Texas-based shell company owned by Imelda Cuellar and her two children, according to the indictment. The $25,000 a month was paid out under a \"sham contract\" in exchange for \"unspecified consulting services\" according to the Associated Press.\n\n\"In reality, the contract was a sham used to disguise and legitimate the corrupt agreement between Henry Cuellar and the government of Azerbaijan,\" the indictment states.\n\nImelda Cuellar would send a false invoice to the Washington office of the Azerbaijani energy company stating the work she contracted for was complete.\n\n\"In fact, Imelda Cuellar had performed little or no legitimate work under the contract,\" the indictment says.\n\nThe indictment also alleges an Azerbaijani diplomat referred to Henry Cuellar in text messages as \"el Jefe\" or \"boss,\" and also that a member of Cuellar's staff sent multiple emails to officials at the Department of State pressuring them to renew a U.S. passport for an Azerbaijani diplomat's daughter.\n\nCuellar was at one time the co-chair of the Congressional Azerbaijan Caucus.\n\nThe FBI searched the congressman's house in the border city of Laredo in 2022, and Cuellar's attorney at that time said Cuellar was not the target of that investigation. That search was part of a broader investigation related to Azerbaijan that saw FBI agents serve a raft of subpoenas and conduct interviews in Washington, D.C., and Texas, a person with direct knowledge of the probe previously told The Associated Press. The person was not authorized to discuss it publicly and spoke on condition of anonymity.\n\nCuellar also agreed to a series of straight-up \"pay for play\" agreements with Azerbaijan.\n\nCNN:\n\nAmong those promises, prosecutors allege Cuellar agreed to influence US policy through a \"series of legislative measures relating to Azerbaijan's conflict with neighboring Armenia,\" by giving a pro-Azerbaijani speech on the House floor, inserting language \"favored by Azerbaijan\" into legislation and committee reports, and advocating for \"series of legislative measures relating to Azerbaijan's conflict with neighboring Armenia.\"\n\nThe Texas Democrat also allegedly promised to influence financial regulations in a way that would benefit the Mexican bank and its affiliates, including by working to pressure the Executive Branch on anti-money laundering enforcement practices that \"threatened\" their business interest and supporting revisions to the criminal money-laundering statutes.\n\nAccording to the Corruption Index of Transparency International, Azerbaijan is ranked 153 out of 180 nations. Cuellar hit with bribery charges tied to Azerbaijan, Mexican bank - Stabroek News", "body": "WASHINGTON, (Reuters) - U.S. Representative Henry Cuellar and his wife were indicted for allegedly accepting close to $600,000 in bribes in two schemes meant to benefit an Azerbaijani state-owned energy company and an unnamed bank based in Mexico, court papers showed.\n\nThe indictment, returned by a grand jury on Tuesday and unsealed on Friday, said the bribes were laundered through sham consulting contracts into shell companies owned by Imelda Cuellar, the congressman's wife,from December 2014 through at least November 2021.\n\nIn exchange, it says Henry Cuellar sought to use his public position to influence U.S. foreign policy in Azerbaijan's favor and to pressure U.S. government officials to help the Mexican bank lobby against anti-money laundering enforcement policies and payday lending regulations that threatened its business.\n\nBefore the charges were unsealed, Cuellar issued a statement denying the allegations.\n\n\"Both my wife and I are innocent of these allegations,\" said Cuellar.\n\nOne of the most conservative Democrats in the House of Representatives, Cuellar is seeking an 11th two-year term in the Nov. 5 election. He represents a Texas district that borders Mexico and includes Laredo and parts of San Antonio.\n\nOn Friday, a spokesperson for Democratic House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries said Cuellar would be stepping down as the ranking member of the Homeland Security Appropriations subcommittee while the case is pending.\n\nCuellar's home and campaign office in Laredo were searched by federal law enforcement in January 2022, when Cuellar served as a co-chair of the Congressional Azerbaijan Caucus.\n\nIn that capacity, he and several other members of Congress signed a letter urging Congress to provide humanitarian support to assist people displaced following the war between Azerbaijan and Armenia.\n\nThe indictment cited Cuellar's support for providing funding to Azerbaijan and a pro-Azerbaijan speech he gave on the House floor, among other actions.\n\nCuellar said in his statement he had sought legal advice from the House Ethics Committee and a national law firm.\n\n\"We requested a meeting with the Washington DC prosecutors to explain the facts and they refused to discuss the case with us or to hear our side,\" he added.", "source": {"uri": "stabroeknews.com", {"uri": "2024-05-344427069", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-03", "time": "21:37:50", "dateTime": "2024-05-03T21:37:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-03T15:34:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://www.wxow.com/news/politics/rep-henry-cuellar-and-his-wife-allegedly-took-nearly-600-000-in-bribes-indictment-says/article_a901117a-a1f1-5095-9407-ba194f8cfe07.html", "title": "Rep. Henry Cuellar and his wife allegedly took nearly $600,000 in bribes, indictment says", "body": "Democratic Rep. Henry Cuellar of Texas and his wife have been charged with accepting nearly $600,000 in bribes from two foreign entities, according to an indictment in federal court in Texas.\n\nThe alleged scheme took place from late 2014 through at least November 2021, the indictment says.\n\nThe congressman and his wife, Imelda Cuellar, made their initial court appearance on Friday in Houston and were released on a $100,000 bond. They are facing several charges, including conspiracy to commit bribery of a federal official, violating the ban on public officials acting as agents of a foreign principal and money laundering.\n\nIn a statement on Friday, Cuellar said: \"I want to be clear that both my wife and I are innocent of these allegations. Everything I have done in Congress has been to serve the people of South Texas.\"\n\nCuellar said in his statement that actions he took in Congress were \"in the interest of the American people\" and vowed to continue his bid for reelection in November. The congressman also defended his wife, saying that, \"The allegation that she is anything but qualified and hard working is both wrong and offensive.\"\n\n\"The actions I took in Congress were consistent with the actions of many of my colleagues and in the interest of the American people,\" Cuellar said.\n\nProsecutors say that Henry and Imelda Cuellar crafted two yearslong schemes to get bribes from foreign entities - an oil and gas company \"wholly owned and controlled by the Government of Azerbaijan, and a bank headquartered in Mexico City.\"\n\nIn exchange for bribe payments from the Azerbaijan oil company, Cuellar \"agreed to perform official acts in his capacity as a Member of Congress, to commit acts in violation of his official duties, and to act as an agent of the Government of Azerbaijan\" and the bank, the indictment says.\n\nAmong those promises, prosecutors allege Cuellar agreed to influence US policy through a \"series of legislative measures relating to Azerbaijan's conflict with neighboring Armenia,\" by giving a pro-Azerbaijani speech on the House floor, inserting language \"favored by Azerbaijan\" into legislation and committee reports, and advocating for \"series of legislative measures relating to Azerbaijan's conflict with neighboring Armenia.\"\n\nThe Texas Democrat also allegedly promised to influence financial regulations in a way that would benefit the Mexican bank and its affiliates, including by working to pressure the Executive Branch on anti-money laundering enforcement practices that \"threatened\" their business interest and supporting revisions to the criminal money-laundering statutes.\n\nThe couple received the bribe payments through shell companies owned by Imelda Cuellar, prosecutors say. They allegedly used the proceeds from the bribery schemes to pay taxes, pay down debt and spend tens of thousands of dollars at restaurants and retail stores. One purchase was for a $12,000 custom gown, according to the indictment.\n\nCuellar's home and campaign office in Laredo, Texas, were raided by the FBI in 2022. The charges against Cuellar are not yet publicly available.\n\nHouse Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries released a statement shortly after Cuellar's charges were reported, saying that the congressman is entitled to the presumption of innocence. But, Jeffries said, Cuellar will temporarily step down from his top spot on a House Appropriations Subcommittee while the investigation is ongoing.\n\n\"Henry Cuellar has admirably devoted his career to public service and is a valued Member of the House Democratic Caucus. Like any American, Congressman Cuellar is entitled to his day in court and the presumption of innocence throughout the legal process,\" Jeffries said.\n\nThe National Republican Congressional Committee swiftly called on Cuellar to resign.\n\n\"If his colleagues truly believe in putting 'people over politics,' they will call on him to resign. If not -- they are hypocrites whose statements about public service aren't worth the paper they're written on,\" Delanie Bomar, a spokesperson for the NRCC, said in a statement.\n\nThis story and headline have been updated with additional developments.\n\nThe-CNN-Wire\n\n\u2122 & \u00a9 2024 Cable News Network, Inc., a Warner Bros. Discovery Company. {"uri": "8110300679", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-03", "time": "21:37:33", "dateTime": "2024-05-03T21:37:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-03T21:36:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://www.unionleader.com/news/politics/national/rep-cuellar-hit-with-bribery-charges-tied-to-azerbaijan-mexican-bank/article_559cd953-c613-516b-a30a-6412492be4c0.html", "title": "Rep. Cuellar hit with bribery charges tied to Azerbaijan, Mexican bank", "body": "WASHINGTON -- Rep. Henry Cuellar and his wife were indicted for allegedly accepting close to $600,000 in bribes in two schemes meant to benefit an Azerbaijani state-owned energy company and an unnamed bank based in Mexico, court papers showed.\n\nThe indictment, returned by a grand jury on Tuesday and unsealed on Friday, said the bribes were laundered through sham consulting contracts into shell companies owned by Imelda Cuellar, the congressman's wife, from December 2014 through at least November 2021.\n\nIn exchange, it says Henry Cuellar sought to use his public position to influence U.S. foreign policy in Azerbaijan's favor and to pressure U.S. government officials to help the Mexican bank lobby against anti-money laundering enforcement policies and payday lending regulations that threatened its business.\n\nBefore the charges were unsealed, Cuellar issued a statement denying the allegations.\n\n\"Both my wife and I are innocent of these allegations,\" said Cuellar.\n\nOne of the most conservative Democrats in the House of Representatives, Cuellar is seeking an 11th two-year term in the Nov. 5 election. He represents a Texas district that borders Mexico and includes Laredo and parts of San Antonio.\n\nOn Friday, a spokesperson for Democratic House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries said Cuellar would be stepping down as the ranking member of the Homeland Security Appropriations subcommittee while the case is pending.\n\nCuellar's home and campaign office in Laredo were searched by federal law enforcement in January 2022, when Cuellar served as a co-chair of the Congressional Azerbaijan Caucus.\n\nIn that capacity, he and several other members of Congress signed a letter urging Congress to provide humanitarian support to assist people displaced following the war between Azerbaijan and Armenia.\n\nThe indictment cited Cuellar's support for providing funding to Azerbaijan and a pro-Azerbaijan speech he gave on the House floor, among other actions.\n\nCuellar said in his statement he had sought legal advice from the House Ethics Committee and a national law firm.\n\n\"We requested a meeting with the Washington DC prosecutors to explain the facts and they refused to discuss the case with us or to hear our side,\" he added.\n\nThe Justice Department said Cuellar and his wife made initial appearances before a federal magistrate judge in Houston on Friday. They were released on bond.\n\nEach faces 14 counts on charges including conspiracy, bribery, honest services wire fraud, being a public official acting as an agent of a foreign principal, and money laundering.\n\nSeveral of the charges carry a statutory maximum of 20 years in prison.\n\nCuellar is not the only member of Congress facing federal charges.\n\nDemocratic Sen. Bob Menendez is awaiting trial on corruption charges in New York, while Republican George Santos last year was expelled from the House while he awaits trial on charges of violating campaign finance laws.\n\nBoth Menendez and Santos deny wrongdoing.", "source": {"uri": "unionleader.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "UnionLeader.com"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8109951118", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-03", "time": "16:09:32", "dateTime": "2024-05-03T16:09:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-03T16:09:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://www.texastribune.org/2024/05/03/henry-cuellar-texas-indicted-doj/", "title": "Texas Congressman Henry Cuellar declares innocence amid report of inc...", "body": "Sign up for The Brief, The Texas Tribune's daily newsletter that keeps readers up to speed on the most essential Texas news.\n\nWASHINGTON -- U.S. Rep. Henry Cuellar, D-Laredo, asserted his innocence in a statement Friday after NBC News reported federal investigators were planning to indict the long-time congressman.\n\nThe nature of the potential indictment remains unclear. FBI agents raideded Cuellar's Laredo home and office in 2022 -- weeks before his primary election -- though his lawyer at the time asserted he was not the target of the investigation. ABC News reported shortly after that the investigation was related to Cuellar, his wife and one of his campaign staffers and their alleged ties to Azerbaijan. Cuellar is a member of the Congressional Azerbaijan Caucus.\n\nIn his Friday statement, Cuellar said his actions were \"consistent with the actions of many of my colleagues and in the interest of the American people.\"\n\n\"I want to be clear that both my wife and I are innocent of these allegations,\" Cuellar said without addressing what the allegations were about. \"Before I took any action, I proactively sought legal advice from the House Ethics Committee, who gave me more than one written opinion, along with an additional opinion from a national law firm.\"\n\nThe Texas Tribune and several national news organizations asked a federal court to unseal the search warrant in 2022.\n\nCuellar added that he will still run for reelection in November.\n\nThe 2022 search on Cuellar's home came only a few months before a competitive primary against progressive candidate Jessica Cisneros, a Laredo-based immigration attorney. He ended up winning in the primary by 0.6 percentage points.\n\nCuellar is the fourth-longest serving Democrat in the Texas delegation and is an established fixture in the House Democratic Caucus. He is known for his centrist policy priorities, including votes reflecting his personal aversion to abortion and in support of stricter border security.\n\nHe is also a major proponent of the oil and gas industry, which is responsible for a large part of his district's economy. Azerbaijan is a major oil and gas producer.\n\nStill, he is well respected within the Democratic Caucus for his prolific fundraising and reliability on major votes that count. Democratic leadership under Speaker Nancy Pelosi supported Cuellar when Cisneros challenged him in the 2020 and 2022 primaries. Cuellar won in both primaries and the 2022 general election, despite heavy investment from Republicans to flip South Texas. He beat his 2022 Republican opponent, Cassy Garcia, by over 13 points.\n\nTwo Republican challengers will face off in a May 28 runoff for the chance to challenge Cuellar in the general: Jay Furman and Lazaro Garzo. After Cuellar's 2022 win, Republicans have considered the district less competitive and are investing more heavily in the nearby Rio Grande Valley-based 15th and 34th districts.", "source": {"uri": Henry Cuellar (D-TX) is insisting he is innocent after reports that the Justice Department may announce an indictment of the representative as soon as Friday.\n\nCuellar said in a statement that he and his wife are innocent and \"everything I have done in Congress has been to serve the people of South Texas.\"\n\n\"Before I took any action, I proactively sought legal advice from the House Ethics Committee, who gave me more than one written opinion, along with an additional opinion from a national law firm,\" the Texas Democrat said. \"The actions I took in Congress were consistent with the actions of many of my colleagues and in the interest of the American people.\"\n\n\"These allegations have been difficult on my family,\" Cuellar continued. \"But, with your prayers, we will overcome.\"\n\nCuellar noted that he is still running for re-election in November and \"will win.\"\n\nFeatured Local Savings\n\nNBC News reported on Friday morning that the DOJ was preparing to indict Cuellar. Though his seat is rated \"likely Democratic\" by Cook Political Report, an indictment could slim his reelection chances.\n\nA member of the House's centrist Blue Dogs and New Democrat Coalitions, Cuellar came to Congress in 2004. He is the sole House Democrat who opposes abortion rights, a flashpoint for several members of his own party.\n\nSign Up for Springs AM Update Your morning rundown of the latest news from Colorado Springs and around the country\n\nSign Up View all of our newsletters. Henry Cuellar of Texas and his wife were indicted on conspiracy and bribery charges and taken into custody Friday in connection with a U.S. Department of Justice probe into the couple's ties to Azerbaijan, AP reported.\n\nFrom 2014 to 2021, Cuellar, 68, and his wife accepted nearly $600,000 in bribes from an Azerbaijan-controlled energy company and a bank in Mexico, and in exchange, Cuellar agreed to advance the interests of the country and the bank in the U.S., according to the indictment.\n\nAmong other things, Cuellar agreed to influence legislation favorable to Azerbaijan and deliver a pro-Azerbaijan speech on the floor of the U.S. House, the indictment states.\n\nThe Department of Justice said the couple surrendered to authorities on Friday and were taken into custody. They made an initial appearance before a federal judge in Houston and were each released on $100,000 bond, the DOJ said.\n\nThe longtime congressman released a statement Friday saying he and his wife, Imelda Cuellar, 67, \"are innocent of these allegations.\"\n\nIn addition to bribery and conspiracy, the couple face charges including wire fraud conspiracy, acting as agents of foreign principals and money laundering. If convicted, they face up to decades in prison and forfeiture of any property linked to proceeds from the alleged scheme.\n\nThe payments to the couple initially went through a Texas-based shell company owned by Imelda Cuellar and two of the couple's children, according to the indictment. That company received payments from the Azerbaijan energy company of $25,000 per month under a \"sham contract,\" purportedly in exchange for unspecified strategic consulting and advising services.\n\n\"In reality, the contract was a sham used to disguise and legitimate the corrupt agreement between Henry Cuellar and the government of Azerbaijan,\" the indictment states.\n\nImelda Cuellar sent a falsified invoice to the Azerbaijan energy company's Washington, D.C., office under the agreement, stating her work was complete.\n\n\"In fact, Imelda Cuellar had performed little or no legitimate work under the contract,\" the indictment says.\n\nThe indictment also alleges an Azerbaijani diplomat referred to Henry Cuellar in text messages as \"el Jefe\" or \"boss,\" and also that a member of Cuellar's staff sent multiple emails to officials at the Department of State pressuring them to renew a U.S. passport for an Azerbaijani diplomat's daughter.\n\nCuellar was at one time the co-chair of the Congressional Azerbaijan Caucus.", "source": {"uri": "panorama.am", "dataType": "news", "title": "\u054a\u0561\u0576\u0578\u0580\u0561\u0574\u0561"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8112135294", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "09:28:45", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T09:28:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T09:28:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://www.newstribune.com/news/2024/may/05/congressman-vows-to-continue-bid-for-11th-term/", "title": "Congressman vows to continue bid for 11th term despite bribery indictment", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- For two decades, U.S. Rep. Henry Cuellar has stood out as a moderate Democrat along the Texas-Mexico border, bucking his party at times over guns and immigration while seldom facing a tough reelection.\n\nBut a federal indictment accusing Cuellar of federal conspiracy and bribery charges is putting the Laredo native who was first elected in 2004 in a different spotlight. Cuellar, 68, and his wife, Imelda, 67, were taken into custody Friday in connection with a U.S. Department of Justice probe into the couple's ties to the former Soviet republic of Azerbaijan.\n\nThe congressman professed his innocence after the indictment was revealed and vowed to continue his bid for an 11th term in November, saying, \"Everything I have done in Congress has been to serve the people of South Texas.\"\n\nThe Cuellars are accused of accepting nearly $600,000 in bribes from an Azerbaijan-controlled energy company and a bank in Mexico. In exchange, Cuellar allegedly agreed to advance those entities' interests in the U.S.\n\nThe couple surrendered to authorities, made an initial appearance before a federal judge in Houston and were each released on $100,000 bond, the DOJ said.\n\nCuellar's family is a political fixture along the border: His brother is the sheriff in Laredo, and his sister, a former municipal judge, is also on the ballot this year, running as a Democratic candidate for state representative.\n\nSeveral of Cuellar's allies in the district, which stretches from the Rio Grande to the San Antonio suburbs, expressed surprise over the indictments, but said they would still support his reelection. Cuellar's moderate politics have helped him maintain support in places where Democrats have lost ground, like Starr County, a rural and agricultural part of South Texas.\n\n\"It is extremely surprising for me because I've known Henry for many, many years,\" Starr County Judge Eloy Vera said. \"He's always been a very straight guy, you know, very sincere. I mean, he's done so much for us in Starr County. I hate to see this going on.\"\n\nSylvia Bruni, chair of nearby Webb County's Democratic Party, said she would trust the legal system to work fairly and her focus would remain on elections. \"We have a campaign to advance, our Democracy at stake,\" she said in a statement.\n\nCuellar released a statement Friday saying he and his wife \"are innocent of these allegations.\"\n\n\"Before I took action, I proactively sought legal advice from the House Ethics Committee, who gave me more than one written opinion, along with an additional opinion from a national law firm,\" the statement said.\n\n\"Furthermore, we requested a meeting with the Washington D.C. prosecutors to explain the facts and they refused to discuss the case with us or hear our side.\"\n\nIn addition to bribery and conspiracy, the couple face charges including wire fraud conspiracy, acting as agents of foreign principals and money laundering. If convicted, they could be punished with up to decades in prison and forfeiture of any property linked to proceeds from the alleged scheme.\n\nThe payments to the couple initially went through a Texas-based shell company owned by Imelda Cuellar and two of the couple's children, according to the indictment. That company received payments from the Azerbaijan energy company of $25,000 per month under a \"sham contract,\" purportedly in exchange for unspecified strategic consulting and advising services.\n\n\"In reality, the contract was a sham used to disguise and legitimate the corrupt agreement between Henry Cuellar and the government of Azerbaijan,\" the indictment says.\n\nImelda Cuellar is alleged to have sent a falsified invoice to the energy company's Washington, D.C., office under the agreement, saying her work was complete.\n\n\"In fact, Imelda Cuellar had performed little or no legitimate work under the contract,\" the indictment says.\n\nThe indictment alleges an Azerbaijani diplomat referred to Henry Cuellar in text messages as both \"el Jefe\" and \"boss,\" and also that a member of Cuellar's staff sent multiple emails to officials at the State Department pressuring them to renew a U.S. passport for an Azerbaijani diplomat's daughter.\n\nCuellar was at one time the co-chair of the Congressional Azerbaijan Caucus.\n\nThe FBI searched the congressman's house in the border city of Laredo in 2022, and Cuellar's attorney at that time said he was not the target of the investigation.\n\nFILE - Federal agents search the home of Rep. Henry Cuellar, D-Texas, in Laredo, Texas, Jan. 19, 2022. Cuellar and his wife were indicted on conspiracy and bribery charges and taken into custody Friday, May 3, 2024, in connection with a U.S. Department of Justice probe into the couple's ties to the former Soviet republic of Azerbaijan. Officials with the U.S. Department of Justice did not immediately confirm the indictments.\n\nNBC News, CNN and Fox News, all citing unnamed sources familiar with the matter, reported Friday the Justice Department was expected to announce Cuellar's indictment.\n\nCuellar was at one time the co-chair of the Congressional Azerbaijan Caucus.\n\nThe FBI searched the congressman's house in the border city of Laredo in 2022, and Cuellar's attorney at that time said Cuellar was not the target of that investigation. That search was part of a broader investigation related to Azerbaijan that saw FBI agents serve a raft of subpoenas and conduct interviews in Washington, D.C., and Texas, a person with direct knowledge of the probe previously told The Associated Press. The person was not authorized to discuss it publicly and spoke on condition of anonymity.", "source": {"uri": "bostonglobe.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Boston Globe"}, "authors": [], Henry Cuellar indicted on bribery, conspiracy charges", "body": "WASHINGTON (TND) -- Longtime Democratic Texas Congressman Henry Cuellar was indicted by the Department of Justice on charges of conspiracy and bribery in connection with an investigation between U.S. businesses and Azerbaijan.\n\nProsecutors allege Cuellar and his wife accepted nearly $600,000 in bribes from an energy company controlled by Azerbaijan and a bank in Mexico. In exchange, Cueller agreed to advance their interests in the U.S., according to investigators. Cuellar is accused of agreeing to influence legislation that was favorable to Azerbaijan and deliver a pro-Azerbaijan speech on the floor of the House of Representatives.\n\nFederal investigators raided Cuellar's home in Laredo and his campaign office in 2022.\n\nHis legal counsel previously said Cuellar was not the target of the investigation.\n\nCuellar released a statement to NBC News claiming he and his wife are innocent.\n\n\"I want to be clear that both my wife and I are innocent of these allegations. Everything I have done in Congress has been to serve the people of South Texas,\" Cuellar's statement read in part.\n\nThat search was part of a broader investigation related to Azerbaijan that saw FBI agents serve a raft of subpoenas and conduct interviews in Washington, D.C., and Texas, a person with direct knowledge of the probe previously told The Associated Press. {"uri": "8110209158", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-03", "time": "20:01:02", "dateTime": "2024-05-03T20:01:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-03T19:57:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/texas-democrat-henry-cuellar-wife-181957302.html", "title": "Texas Democrat Henry Cuellar and wife indicted over allegations of $600,000 bribes from Azerbaijan", "body": "Texas Democratic Representative Henry Cuellar and his wife have been indicted by federal prosecutors on charges of conspiracy and bribery, after allegedly taking nearly $600,000 from a Azerbaijani-controlled company and a Mexican bank.\n\nThe charges were announced on Friday by the US Department of Justice (DOJ), shortly after Mr Cuellar protested his innocence.\n\nIt is alleged that from 2014 to 2021, Mr Cuellar and his wife Imelda accepted nearly $600,000 in bribes from an Azerbaijan-controlled energy company and a bank in Mexico, and in exchange, the congressman agreed to advance the interests of the country and the bank in the US, according to an indictment.\n\nThe money was also allegedly laundered through a series of front companies and middlemen into shell companies owned by Ms Cuellar.\n\nAmong other things, Mr Cuellar allegedly agreed to influence legislation favorable to Azerbaijan and deliver a pro-Azerbaijan speech on the floor of the US House.\n\nThe announcement comes after the congressman released a statement earlier on Friday in which he claimed that \"everything I have done in Congress has been to serve the people of South Texas.\"\n\n\"I want to be clear that both my wife and I are innocent of these allegations,\" Mr Cuellar said. \"Before I took action, I proactively sought legal advice from the House Ethics Committee, who gave me more than one written opinion, along with an additional opinion from a national law firm.\n\n\"Furthermore, we requested a meeting with the Washington DC prosecutors to explain the facts and they refused to discuss the case with us or hear our side.\"\n\nHe added that the actions he took in Congress were \"consistent with the actions of many of my colleagues and in the interest of the American people.\"\n\nA conservative Democrat, Mr Cuellar has long been a target of progressives given his opposition to abortion rights. In 2020 and 2022, Jessica Cisneros staged a primary challenger against him, sending him to a runoff, in which he prevailed both times.\n\nHouse Democratic leadership has consistently backed him and belive that he is the only Democrat who can win in the heavily conservative and Latino Rio Grande Valley. In his most recent primary in March, he ran unopposed.\n\nMr Cuellar has also sharply criticised other Democrats for their policies on immigration and started a coterie of Democrats who support stronger measures called Democrats for Border Security Task Force.\n\nHe was at one time the co-chair of the Congressional Azerbaijan Caucus.\n\nMr Cuellar's family also has a prominent presence in the district. His brother is the sheriff of Webb County while his sister served as a judge for Rio Bravo and Webb County. His concentration of power has earned him the nickname \"the King Laredo,\" where he lives.\n\nIn 2022, the FBI raided Mr Cuellar's congressional office in Laredo and his home. His attorney at that time said the congressman was not the target of that investigation.\n\nThat search was part of a broader investigation related to Azerbaijan that saw FBI agents serve a raft of subpoenas and conduct interviews in Washington DC, and Texas, a person with direct knowledge of the probe previously told The Associated Press.\n\nFederal disclosures show that the nine-term congressman traveled to Azerbaijan in 2013. Two years later, Mr Cuellar's office announced an agreement between a Texas university and an organization called the Assembly of Friends of Azerbaijan for the purposes of collaborating on oil and gas research and education.\n\nDespite the controversy surrounding the raids in 2022, Mr Cuellar went on to beat back a left-wing Democratic challenger - Jessica Cisneros - for the second time.\n\nA year after the raid on his home the congressman told the Texas Tribune: \"There has been no wrongdoing on my part... My focus remains the same from my very first day in office: delivering results for Texans across my district.\"\n\nMr Cuellar has previously been undaunted by the controversy and has previously vowed to seek reelection to Congress in November, which would be his 11th term.\n\nFollowing the announcement of charges, House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries said that the congressman was \"entitled to his day in court.\"\n\n\"Henry Cuellar has admirably devoted his career to public service and is a valued Member of the House Democratic Caucus. Like any American, Congressman Cuellar is entitled to his day in court and the presumption of innocence throughout the legal process,\" a statement from Mr Jeffries read.\n\n\"Pursuant to House Democratic Caucus Rule 24, Congressman Cuellar will take leave as Ranking Member of the Homeland Security Appropriations Subcommittee while this matter is ongoing.\"\n\nIn contrast, the National Republican Congressional Committee (NRCC) wrote in a brief post on X: \"Cuellar does not put Texas first, he puts himself first. Will House Democrats call for him to RESIGN?\"", "source": {"uri": "ca.news.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": Everything I have done in Congress has been to serve the people of South Texas,\" Cuellar said in a statement that did not elaborate on what he was accused of.\n\nHe added that \"I'm running for re-election and will win this November,\" when Democrats are hoping to regain the majority in the House of Representatives.\n\nHis comments came after NBC News, citing two unnamed sources, reported federal charges would soon be announced against the lawmaker, who has represented a swath of Texas's border with Mexico in Congress's lower chamber since 2005. It was not clear what Cuellar was being charged with.\n\nTwo years ago, the FBI raided Cuellar's Laredo, Texas, home and campaign office as part of an investigation into US businessmen and links with Azerbaijan. At the time, the congressman said he would cooperate fully with the FBI, but it remains unclear if Cuellar's expected indictment was related to that search. Months later, an attorney for Cuellar told Fox News that the congressman was not a target of the investigation that led to the raid.\n\nIn his statement on Friday, the congressman said that \"before I took any action, I proactively sought legal advice from the House Ethics Committee, who gave me more than one written opinion, along with an additional opinion from a national law firm. The actions I took in Congress were consistent with the actions of many of my colleagues and in the interest of the American people.\" He did not elaborate on what action he was referring to, or how his wife, Imelda Cuellar, was involved.\n\nCuellar added that he had requested to meet with \"the Washington, DC prosecutors to explain the facts and they refused to discuss the case with us or to hear our side\".\n\nFederal charges could complicate the re-election of 68-year-old Cuellar, who is seeking an 11th term in office. abortion access.\n\nAfter the 2022 raid on his home and office, Cuellar narrowly won the Democratic primary against his progressive challenger, Jessica Cisneros, then easily beat Republican Cassy {"uri": "8109914406", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-03", "time": "15:42:03", "dateTime": "2024-05-03T15:42:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-03T15:41:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "url": "https://nypost.com/2024/05/03/us-news/texas-democrat-rep-henry-cuellar-to-be-indicted-by-justice-department/", "title": "Texas Democrat Rep. Henry Cuellar to be indicted by Justice Department", "body": "The Justice Department is expected to announce later Friday that Rep. Henry Cuellar (D-Texas) has been indicted on unknown charges.\n\nCuellar, a pro-life moderate who has been critical of President Biden's handling of the border crisis, issued a statement shortly after NBC News reported that an indictment would be made public.\n\nIn the statement, Cuellar said he and his wife Imelda were \"innocent of these allegations\" and added that he had acted \"consistent with the actions of many of my colleagues and in the interest of the American people.\"\n\nIn January 2022, Cuellar's home and campaign office in Laredo, Texas were searched by federal investigators in connection with a larger probe into ties between the former Soviet republic of Azerbaijan and multiple US businessmen.\n\nAt the time, Cuellar -- a co-chair of the bipartisan Congressional Azerbaijan Caucus -- vowed to \"fully cooperate in any investigation.\"\n\nThat November, the now-68-year-old was elected to a 10th House term and concluded his statement Friday by saying: \"Let me be clear, I'm running for re-election and will win this November.\"", "source": {"uri": "nypost.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "New York Post"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-05-344608003", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-04", "time": "04:43:56", "dateTime": "2024-05-04T04:43:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-04T04:18:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "url": "https://www.wral.com/story/rep-henry-cuellar-of-texas-vows-to-continue-his-bid-for-an-11th-term-despite-bribery-indictment/21413905/", "title": "Rep. Henry Cuellar of Texas vows to continue his bid for an 11th term despite bribery indictment", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- For two decades, U.S. Rep. Henry Cuellar has stood out as a moderate Democrat along the Texas-Mexico border, bucking his party at times over guns and immigration while seldom facing a tough reelection.\n\nBut a federal indictment accusing Cuellar of federal conspiracy and bribery charges is putting the Laredo native who was first elected in 2004 in a different spotlight. Cuellar, 68, and his wife, Imelda, 67, were taken into custody Friday in connection with a U.S. Department of Justice probe into the couple's ties to the former Soviet republic of Azerbaijan.\n\nThe congressman professed his innocence after the indictment was revealed and vowed to continue his bid for an 11th term in November, saying, \"Everything I have done in Congress has been to serve the people of South Texas.\"\n\nThe Cuellars are accused of accepting nearly $600,000 in bribes from an Azerbaijan-controlled energy company and a bank in Mexico. In exchange, Cuellar allegedly agreed to advance those entities' interests in the U.S.\n\nThe couple surrendered to authorities, made an initial appearance before a federal judge in Houston and were each released on $100,000 bond, the DOJ said.\n\nCuellar's family is a political fixture along the border: His brother is the sheriff in Laredo, and his sister, a former municipal judge, is also on the ballot this year, running as a Democratic candidate for state representative.\n\nSeveral of Cuellar's allies in the district, which stretches from the Rio Grande to the San Antonio suburbs, expressed surprise over the indictments but said they would still support his reelection. Cuellar's moderate politics have helped him maintain support in places where Democrats have lost ground, like Starr County, a rural and agricultural part of South Texas.\n\n\"It is extremely surprising for me because I've known Henry for many, many years,\" Starr County Judge Eloy Vera said. \"He's always been a very straight guy, you know, very sincere. I mean, he's done so much for us in Starr County. I hate to see this going on.\"\n\nPresident Joe Biden won Starr County by a slim, single-digit margin. Two years later, Cuellar won it by 40%.\n\nSylvia Bruni, chair of nearby Webb County's Democratic Party, said she would trust the legal system to work fairly and her focus would remain on elections. \"We have a campaign to advance, our Democracy at stake,\" she said in a statement.\n\nCuellar released a statement Friday saying he and his wife \"are innocent of these allegations.\"\n\n\"Before I took action, I proactively sought legal advice from the House Ethics Committee, who gave me more than one written opinion, along with an additional opinion from a national law firm,\" the statement said.\n\n\"Furthermore, we requested a meeting with the Washington D.C. prosecutors to explain the facts and they refused to discuss the case with us or hear our side.\"\n\nIn addition to bribery and conspiracy, the couple face charges including wire fraud conspiracy, acting as agents of foreign principals and money laundering. If convicted, they could be punished with up to decades in prison and forfeiture of any property linked to proceeds from the alleged scheme.\n\nThe payments to the couple initially went through a Texas-based shell company owned by Imelda Cuellar and two of the couple's children, according to the indictment. That company received payments from the Azerbaijan energy company of $25,000 per month under a \"sham contract,\" purportedly in exchange for unspecified strategic consulting and advising services.\n\n\"In reality, the contract was a sham used to disguise and legitimate the corrupt agreement between Henry Cuellar and the government of Azerbaijan,\" the indictment says.\n\nImelda Cuellar is alleged to have sent a falsified invoice to the energy company's Washington, D.C., office under the agreement, saying her work was complete.\n\n\"In fact, Imelda Cuellar had performed little or no legitimate work under the contract,\" the indictment says.\n\nThe indictment alleges that an Azerbaijani diplomat referred to Henry Cuellar in text messages as both \"el Jefe\" and \"boss,\" and also that a member of Cuellar's staff sent multiple emails to officials at the State Department pressuring them to renew a U.S. passport for an Azerbaijani diplomat's daughter.\n\nCuellar was at one time the co-chair of the Congressional Azerbaijan Caucus.\n\nThe FBI searched the congressman's house in the border city of Laredo in 2022, and Cuellar's attorney at that time said he was not the target of the investigation.\n\nCuellar, one of the last anti-abortion Democrats in Congress, narrowly defeated progressive challenger Jessica Cisneros by fewer than 300 votes in a primary race in 2022. Cuellar has been among his party's loudest critics of Biden, particularly over the administration's response to a record number of migrant crossings on the border. His moderate politics have aligned him at times with Republicans on issues including abortion and guns. ___\n\nGonzalez reported from McAllen, Texas. Henry Cuellar", "body": "The Justice Department on Friday is expected to announce the indictment of US Rep. Henry Cuellar, a Texas Democrat, a source familiar with the situation told CNN.\n\nCuellar's home and campaign office in Laredo, Texas, were raided by the FBI in 2022. The charges against Cuellar are not yet publicly available.\n\nThe Justice Department declined to comment.\n\nIn a statement on Friday, Cuellar said: \"I want to be clear that both my wife and I are innocent of these allegations. Everything I have done in Congress has been to serve the people of South Texas.\"\n\nNBC News first reported the Justice Department's plans.\n\nCuellar said in his statement that actions he took in Congress were \"in the interest of the American people\" and vowed to continue his bid for reelection in November.\n\nIn his statement, he suggested his wife, Imelda, was involved.\n\n\"On top of being an amazing wife and mother, she's an accomplished businesswoman with two degrees. She spent her career working with banking, tax, and consulting,\" Cuellar said. \"The allegation that she is anything but qualified and hard working is both wrong and offensive.\"\n\nCuellar also said that before he took any action, he \"proactively\" sought legal advice from the House Ethics Committee and an opinion from a national law firm, and sought a meeting with federal prosecutors \"to explain the facts.\"\n\n\"The actions I took in Congress were consistent with the actions of many of my colleagues and in the interest of the American people,\" Cuellar said. \"Furthermore, we requested a meeting with the Washington DC prosecutors to explain the facts and they refused to discuss the case with us or to hear our side.\"\n\nThis story has been updated with additional developments.\n\nThe-CNN-Wire\n\n\u2122 & \u00a9 2024 Cable News Network, Inc., a Warner Bros. {"uri": "8110204362", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-03", "time": "19:54:05", "dateTime": "2024-05-03T19:54:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-03T19:52:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "url": "https://gazette.com/news/wex/henry-cuellar-indicted-doj-charges-texas-house-democrat-with-taking-bribes/article_154ca08b-3a03-5229-8a1b-32d0d1575783.html", "title": "Henry Cuellar indicted: DOJ charges Texas House Democrat with taking bribes", "body": "Rep. Henry Cuellar (D-TX) was indicted in Texas on Friday for allegedly accepting nearly $600,000 in bribes from two foreign entities: the government of Azerbaijan and a bank based in Mexico City.\n\nCuellar, a congressman of nearly two decades, and his wife Imelda were both charged by the Department of Justice with conspiracy to commit bribery, bribery of a federal official, conspiracy to commit honest services fraud, violating a ban on public officials acting as foreign agents, and several money laundering charges.\n\nCuellar, who once served as the co-chairman of the Congressional Azerbaijan Caucus, declared that he was innocent hours ahead of the indictment being unsealed.\n\nNBC News reported Friday morning that the DOJ was preparing to bring the indictment against Cuellar. According to the outlet, his staff were calling other member offices on Friday seeking advice on how to handle the situation.\n\nIn January 2022, Cuellar's home and campaign office in Laredo, Texas, were raided as part of the DOJ's investigation into Azerbaijan and those connected to the nation. Cuellar's lawyer later told several news outlets in April of that year that the Texas congressman was informed he was not the target of the investigation.\n\nCuellar said in a statement ahead of the indictment that he and his wife are innocent and that \"everything I have done in Congress has been to serve the people of South Texas.\"\n\nFeatured Local Savings\n\n\"Before I took any action, I proactively sought legal advice from the House Ethics Committee, who gave me more than one written opinion, along with an additional opinion from a national law firm,\" the Texas Democrat said. \"The actions I took in Congress were consistent with the actions of many of my colleagues and in the interest of the American people.\n\n\"These allegations have been difficult on my family,\" Cuellar continued. \"But, with your prayers, we will overcome.\"\n\nCLICK HERE TO READ MORE FROM THE WASHINGTON EXAMINER\n\nOver the last two years, Cuellar has faced tough reelection cycles. In 2022, he narrowly defeated a progressive challenger. This year, two Republican candidates will face each other in a runoff election on May 28 for the opportunity to unseat Cuellar in November.\n\nThough his seat is rated \"likely Democratic\" by the Cook Political Report, an indictment could slim his reelection chances.\n\nThis is a breaking story and will be updated.\n\nSign Up for Springs AM Update Your morning rundown of the latest news from Colorado Springs and around the country\n\nSign Up View all of our newsletters. {"uri": "2024-05-344281504", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-03", "time": "17:55:24", "dateTime": "2024-05-03T17:55:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-03T17:54:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://www.sacbee.com/news/nation-world/national/article288285185.html", "title": "Texas Rep. Henry Cuellar proclaims innocence as unspecified indictment expected", "body": "May 3 (UPI) -- The Justice Department is expected to indict Rep. Henry Cuellar, D-Texas.\n\nNBC, ABC and CNN all reported the expected indictment, citing unnamed sources.\n\nIn a Friday statement, Cuellar said, \"I want to be clear that both my wife and I are innocent of these allegations. Everything I have done in Congress has been to serve the people of South Texas.\"\n\nHe added, \"Furthermore, we requested a meeting with the Washington, D.C., prosecutors to explain the facts and they refused to discuss the case with us or to hear our side.\"\n\nHe said he would run for re-election in November.\n\nWithout specifying the allegation, Cuellar said the allegation that his wife is \"anything but qualified and hard-working is both wrong and offensive.\"\n\nIn a statement, the National Republican Congressional Campaign Committee said, \"Henry Cuellar does not put Texas first, he puts himself first. If his colleagues truly believe in putting 'people over politics,' they will call on him to resign. If not -- they are hypocrites whose statements about public service aren't worth the paper they're written on.\"\n\nThe Justice Department declined to comment. Cuellar said he has sought advice from the House Ethics Committee and a national law firm on how to respond.\n\nA source familiar with the situation told CNN that the Justice Department is expected to indict Cuellar. The charges have not been made public.\n\nIn January 2022, the FBI searched Cuellar's home and a building where his campaign headquarters was located, saying only that it was a \"court-authorized\" search.\n\nIt's unknown whether that search and the expected indictment are related.\n\nABC News cited a source familiar with the matter who said the 2022 FBI search was part of a larger federal investigation related to the former Soviet state of Azerbaijan and some U.S. businessmen.\n\nFederal grand jury action that led to the FBI search also issued subpoenas of companies and other organizations with links to Azerbaijan. That included records related to Cuellar and his wife, according to ABC News.\n\nCuellar is a former co-chair of the Congressional Azerbaijani Caucus and in that role met with Azerbaijani officials.", "source": {"uri": "sacbee.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Sacramento Bee"}, "authors": [{"uri": "doug_cunningham@sacbee.com", "name": "Doug Cunningham", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}],
