Henry Cuellar of Texas denies wrongdoing amid reports of pending indictment", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- Democratic U.S. Rep. Henry Cuellar of Texas denied any wrongdoing amid reports of pending indictments related to the former Soviet republic of Azerbaijan.\n\nThe longtime congressman released a statement Friday saying he and his wife \"are innocent of these allegations.\"\n\n\"Everything I have done in Congress has been to serve the people of South Texas,\" Cuellar said. \"Before I took action, I proactively sought legal advice from the House Ethics Committee, who gave me more than one written opinion, along with an additional opinion from a national law firm.\n\n\"Furthermore, we requested a meeting with the Washington D.C. prosecutors to explain the facts and they refused to discuss the case with us or hear our side.\"\n\nNeither Cuellar nor his attorney immediately responded to calls seeking comment on the matter. Officials with the U.S. Department of Justice did not immediately confirm the indictments.\n\nNBC News, CNN and Fox News, all citing unnamed sources familiar with the matter, reported Friday the Justice Department was expected to announce Cuellar's indictment.\n\nCuellar was at one time the co-chair of the Congressional Azerbaijan Caucus.\n\nThe FBI searched the congressman's house in the border city of Laredo in 2022, and Cuellar's attorney at that time said Cuellar was not the target of that investigation. That search was part of a broader investigation related to Azerbaijan that saw FBI agents serve a raft of subpoenas and conduct interviews in Washington, D.C., and Texas, a person with direct knowledge of the probe previously told The Associated Press. The person was not authorized to discuss it publicly and spoke on condition of anonymity.\n\nFederal disclosures show that the nine-term congressman traveled to Azerbaijan in 2013. Two years later, Cuellar's office announced an agreement between a Texas university and an organization called the Assembly of Friends of Azerbaijan for the purposes of collaborating on oil and gas research and education.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. {"uri": "8109921677", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-03", "time": "15:47:20", "dateTime": "2024-05-03T15:47:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-03T15:47:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "url": "https://www.click2houston.com/news/texas/2024/05/03/texas-congressman-henry-cuellar-declares-innocence-amid-report-of-incoming-indictment/", "title": "Texas Congressman Henry Cuellar declares innocence amid report of incoming indictment", "body": "Sign up for The Brief, The Texas Tribune's daily newsletter that keeps readers up to speed on the most essential Texas news.\n\nRecommended Videos\n\nWASHINGTON -- U.S. Rep. Henry Cuellar, D-Laredo, asserted his innocence in a statement Friday after NBC News reported federal investigators were planning to indict the long-time congressman.\n\nThe nature of the potential indictment remains unclear. FBI agents raideded Cuellar's Laredo home and office in 2022 -- weeks before his primary election -- though his lawyer at the time asserted he was not the target of the investigation. ABC News reported shortly after that the investigation was related to Cuellar, his wife and one of his campaign staffers and their alleged ties to Azerbaijan. Cellular is a member of the Congressional Azerbaijan Caucus.\n\nIn his Friday statement, Cuellar said his actions were \"consistent with the actions of many of my colleagues and in the interest of the American people.\"\n\n\"I want to be clear that both my wife and I are innocent of these allegations,\" Cuellar said without addressing what the allegations were about. \"Before I took any action, I proactively sought legal advice from the House Ethics Committee, who gave me more than one written opinion, along with an additional opinion from a national law firm.\"\n\nCuellar added that he will still run for reelection in November.\n\nWe've got big things in store for you at The Texas Tribune Festival, happening Sept. 5-7 in downtown Austin. {"uri": "8110127766", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-03", "time": "18:38:01", "dateTime": "2024-05-03T18:38:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-03T18:37:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2024/05/03/us/henry-cuellar-indictment.html", "title": "Henry Cuellar Indicted Over Bribery Scheme", "body": "Representative Henry Cuellar, Democrat of Texas, and his wife were charged with participating in a yearslong $600,000 bribery scheme involving Azerbaijan and a Mexican bank, according to a federal indictment unsealed in Houston on Friday.\n\nMr. Cuellar, 68, and his wife Imelda, 67, are accused of bribery and money laundering in connection with their efforts on behalf of a bank based in Mexico City and an energy company owned by Azerbaijan, according to the 54-page complaint.\n\nMr. Cuellar is also accused of acting as an agent of a foreign entity while serving as a U.S. government official.\n\nThe payments, made from 2014 to 2021, were laundered through \"sham consulting contracts,\" front companies and shell companies owned by Mrs. Cuellar, who performed \"little to no legitimate work\" under the contracts, lawyers with the Justice Department's criminal division wrote.\n\nMr. Cuellar \"agreed to influence legislative activity and to advise and pressure high-ranking U.S. executive branch officials regarding measures beneficial to the bank,\" prosecutors said.\n\nMr. Cuellar is one of the more conservative Democrats in the House and the only anti-abortion member of his party in the chamber. The charges are strikingly similar to the indictment brought against Senator Robert Menendez, a Democrat from New Jersey, who was charged with accepting bribes on behalf of Egyptian businesses.\n\nIn a statement before the indictment, Mr. Cuellar maintained his innocence and said he cleared his wife's work with the Ethics Committee. He vowed to run and win re-election despite the charges.\n\n\"I want to be clear that both my wife and I are innocent of these allegations,\" Mr. Cuellar said. \"Everything I have done in Congress has been to serve the people of South Texas.\"\n\n\"Before I took any action,\" he added, \"I proactively sought legal advice from the House Ethics Committee, who gave me more than one written opinion, along with an additional opinion from a national law firm.\"\n\nMr. Cuellar said he tried to meet with federal prosecutors in Washington to explain his side of the story, but they declined the meeting.\n\nThe F.B.I. searched Mr. Cuellar's Laredo home in 2022, but he won a close primary victory anyway over a more progressive challenger, Jessica Cisneros.\n\nRepresentative Hakeem Jeffries of New York, the minority leader, said Mr. Cuellar would take leave from his post as the top Democrat on the Homeland Security Appropriations Subcommittee while he fights the charges.\n\n\"Henry Cuellar has admirably devoted his career to public service and is a valued member of the House Democratic Caucus,\" said Christie Stephenson, a spokeswoman for Mr. Jeffries. \"Like any American, Congressman Henry Cuellar of Texas is set to be indicted by the Department of Justice by the end of the day on Friday, according to a report.\n\nTwo people familiar with an indictment told NBC News on Friday morning that the long-serving congressman will face federal charges.\n\nIt was unknown early Friday afternoon what those charges would be.\n\nCuellar's Laredo, Texas, home and campaign office were raided by federal agents in January 2022.\n\nNBC News said it wasn't known if the coming federal indictment is related to that raid.\n\nThe raid was said to have concerned an investigation into Cuellar and businessmen with ties to Azerbaijan.\n\nSubpoenas were issued and served for both the congressman and his wife, Imelda.\n\nThe Texas Democrat was once the co-chairman of the Congressional Azerbaijan Caucus.\n\nIn a statement to NBC News on Friday, Cuellar defended himself and his wife against any \"allegations\" of wrongdoing.\n\nBut he did not say what crime or crimes he was accused of having committed.\n\n\"I want to be clear that both my wife and I are innocent of these allegations. Everything I have done in Congress has been to serve the people of South Texas,\" Cuellar said. \"The actions I took in Congress were consistent with the actions of many of my colleagues and in the interest of the American people.\"\n\nHe added, \"Imelda and I have been married for 32 years. On top of being an amazing wife and mother, she's an accomplished businesswoman with two degrees. She spent her career working with banking, tax, and consulting.\n\n\"The allegation that she is anything but qualified and hard working is both wrong and offensive.\"\n\nCuellar also told NBC News he will run for re-election this fall no matter what accusations are contained in the expected indictment.\n\n\"Let me be clear, I'm running for re-election and will win this November,\" he said.\n\nCuellar was first elected to represent Texas' 28th Congressional District in 2004.\n\nIn 2022, the congressman defeated his primary challenger, Democrat Jessica Cisneros, by just 281 votes to advance to the general election.\n\nHe defeated Republican candidate Cassy Garcia in the general by double digits, 57 percent to 43 percent.\n\nCuellar, who is the only strongly pro-life Democrat in the House, did not face a primary challenge this year and is a heavy favorite to secure another term.\n\nNBC News reported his staffers were on the phone Friday morning desperately seeking advice from {"uri": "8110204365", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-03", "time": "19:53:32", "dateTime": "2024-05-03T19:53:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-03T19:52:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://gazette.com/news/us-world/us-rep-cuellar-hit-with-bribery-charges-tied-to-azerbaijan-mexican-bank/article_3363c7b6-ac89-5607-8a00-38f9a7737bfc.html", "title": "US Rep. Cuellar hit with bribery charges tied to Azerbaijan, Mexican bank", "body": "By Sarah N. Lynch\n\nWASHINGTON (Reuters) - U.S. Representative Henry Cuellar and his wife were indicted for allegedly accepting close to $600,000 in bribes in two schemes meant to benefit an Azerbaijani state-owned energy company and an unnamed bank based in Mexico, court papers showed.\n\nThe indictment, returned by a grand jury on Tuesday and unsealed on Friday, said the bribes were laundered through sham consulting contracts into shell companies owned by Imelda Cuellar, the congressman's wife, from December 2014 through at least November 2021.\n\nIn exchange, it says Henry Cuellar sought to use his public position to influence U.S. foreign policy in Azerbaijan's favor and to pressure U.S. government officials to help the Mexican bank lobby against anti-money laundering enforcement policies and payday lending regulations that threatened its business.\n\nBefore the charges were unsealed, Cuellar issued a statement denying the allegations.\n\n\"Both my wife and I are innocent of these allegations,\" said Cuellar.\n\nOne of the most conservative Democrats in the House of Representatives, Cuellar is seeking an 11th two-year term in the Nov. 5 election. He represents a Texas district that borders Mexico and includes Laredo and parts of San Antonio.\n\nOn Friday, a spokesperson for Democratic House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries said Cuellar would be stepping down as the ranking member of the Homeland Security Appropriations subcommittee while the case is pending.\n\nCuellar's home and campaign office in Laredo were searched by federal law enforcement in January 2022, when Cuellar served as a co-chair of the Congressional Azerbaijan Caucus.\n\nIn that capacity, he and several other members of Congress signed a letter urging Congress to provide humanitarian support to assist people displaced following the war between Azerbaijan and Armenia.\n\nThe indictment cited Cuellar's support for providing funding to Azerbaijan and a pro-Azerbaijan speech he gave on the House floor, among other actions.\n\nCuellar said in his statement he had sought legal advice from the House Ethics Committee and a national law firm.\n\n\"We requested a meeting with the Washington DC prosecutors to explain the facts and they refused to discuss the case with us or to hear our side,\" he added.\n\nThe Justice Department said Cuellar and his wife made initial appearances before a federal magistrate judge in Houston on Friday. They were released on bond.\n\nEach faces 14 counts on charges including conspiracy, bribery, honest services wire fraud, being a public official acting as an agent of a foreign principal, and money laundering.\n\nSeveral of the charges carry a statutory maximum of 20 years in prison.\n\nCuellar is not the only member of Congress facing federal charges.\n\nDemocratic Senator Bob Menendez is awaiting trial on corruption charges in New York, while Republican George Santos last year was expelled from the House while he awaits trial on charges of violating campaign finance laws.\n\nBoth Menendez and Santos deny wrongdoing.\n\n(Reporting by Sarah N. Lynch; additional reporting by Patricia Zengerle, Doina Chiacu and Richard Cowan; Editing by Scott Malone and Richard Chang)\n\nSign Up for Springs AM Update Your morning rundown of the latest news from Colorado Springs and around the country\n\nSign Up View all of our newsletters. We therefore ask that any funding be routed through either the Government of Azerbaijan or the United Nations, so that U.S. taxpayer resources do not come under Russian control,\" they wrote. Federal prosecutors indicted longtime Texas Congressman Henry Cuellar and his wife on Friday on foreign bribery charges.\n\nThe indictment unsealed in the Southern District of Texas charged the 68-year-old Democrat and wife Imelda Cuellar, 67, with participating in two schemes involving bribery, unlawful foreign influence and money laundering.\n\nBoth made an initial court appearance Friday before U.S. Magistrate Judge Dena Palermo in Houston.\n\nEven before that appearance, Cuellar said he and his wife were innocent.\n\n\"Everything I have done in Congress has been to serve the people of South Texas,\" Cuellar said in a statement Friday. \"Before I took any action, I proactively sought legal advice from the House Ethics Committee, who gave me more than one written opinion, along with an additional opinion from a national law firm.\"\n\nHe also said he sought a meeting with prosecutors.\n\n\"We requested a meeting with the Washington D.C. prosecutors to explain the facts and they refused to discuss the case with us or hear our side,\" he said in the statement.\n\nProsecutors said that Cuellar and his wife accepted about $600,000 in bribes from an oil and gas company owned by the Government of Azerbaijan and a bank headquartered in Mexico City.\n\nProsecutors said the bribe payments were laundered as consulting contracts through a series of front companies and middlemen into shell companies owned by Imelda Cuellar, who they said performed little to no legitimate work under the consulting contracts.\n\nIn exchange, prosecutors said Cuellar agreed to use his office to influence U.S. foreign policy in favor of Azerbaijan. Prosecutors said in exchange for the bribes paid by the Mexican bank, the congressman agreed to influence legislative activity and to advise and pressure high-ranking U.S. officials regarding measures beneficial to the bank.\n\nCuellar previously served as co-chair of the Congressional Azerbaijan Caucus.\n\nCuellar and his wife were both charged with two counts of conspiracy to commit bribery of a federal official and to have a public official act as an agent of a foreign principal, two counts of bribery of a federal official, two counts of conspiracy to commit honest services wire fraud, two counts of violating the ban on public officials acting as agents of a foreign principal, one count of conspiracy to commit concealment money laundering and five counts of money laundering.\n\nThe money laundering charges carry up to 20 years in prison on each count.\n\nFriday's indictment follows a 2022 FBI raid on Cuellar's home and campaign office.\n\nThe FBI and the Department of State's Office of Inspector General investigated the case.\n\nCuellar has represented Texas's 28th Congressional District since 2005. His district includes Laredo and other communities located along the border with Mexico, spanning as far south as Reynosa along the Rio Grande River, stretching northwest to Laredo and northeast to Dean Phillips (D-Minn.) became the first Democrat to call for Rep. Henry Cuellar (D-Texas) to resign in light of the Justice Department (DOJ) indictment he and his wife were hit with on Friday.\n\n\"While the bar for Federal indictment is high, trust in our government is low,\" Phillips said in a post on the social media platform X. \"That's why office holders and candidates under indictment should resign or end their campaigns, including Sen. Bob Menendez, Donald Trump, & Rep. Henry Cuellar.\"\n\nCuellar and his wife were indicted with charges for allegedly getting almost $600,000 in bribes and laundering funds. In the 14-count indictment, the DOJ outlined Cuellar allegedly receiving payments from an Azerbaijani government-owned oil company and a Mexican bank. Both Cuellar and his wife Imelda pleaded not guilty and were released on a $100,000 bond.\n\n\"In exchange for the bribes paid by the Azerbaijani oil and gas company, Congressman Cuellar allegedly agreed to use his office to influence U.S. foreign policy in favor of Azerbaijan,\" the DOJ said in a press release.\n\n\"In exchange for the bribes paid by the Mexican bank, Congressman Cuellar allegedly agreed to influence legislative activity and to advise and pressure high-ranking U.S. Executive Branch officials regarding measures beneficial to the bank.\"\n\nCuellar is the second member of Congress to be under indictment, next to Sen. Bob Menendez (D-N.J.). The New Jersey senator's indictment from the DOJ on bribery charges came last year. The New Jersey senator has been called to resign by more than a dozen Democrats in the upper chamber.\n\nCuellar argued he and his wife did nothing wrong.\n\n\"Before I took any action, I proactively sought legal advice from the House Ethics Committee, who gave me more than one written opinion, along with an additional opinion from a national law firm,\" Cuellar said in a statement issued before the charges were unsealed.\n\n\"The actions I took in Congress were consistent with the actions of many of my colleagues and in the interest of the American people.\"\n\nThe Texas lawmakers said he Henry Cuellar to be indicted, reports say", "body": "WASHINGTON (TND) -- Longtime Democratic Texas Congressman Henry Cuellar is expected to be indicted, according to several reports.\n\nFederal investigators raided Cuellar's home in Laredo and his campaign office in 2022.\n\nHis legal counsel previously said Cuellar was not the target of the investigation.\n\nThat search was part of a broader investigation related to Azerbaijan that saw FBI agents serve a raft of subpoenas and conduct interviews in Washington, D.C., and Texas, a person with direct knowledge of the probe previously told The Associated Press. The person was not authorized to discuss it publicly and spoke on condition of anonymity.\n\nIt's unknown, at this time, if the indictment was related to the 2022 raid.\n\nThe Justice Department is expected to announce the indictment on Friday, according to NBC News.\n\nCuellar released a statement to NBC News claiming he and his wife are innocent.\n\nI want to be clear that both my wife and I are innocent of these allegations. Everything I have done in Congress has been to serve the people of South Texas,\" Cuellar's statement read in part.\n\n\"Everything I have done in Congress has been to serve the people of South Texas,\" Cuellar said. \"Before I took action, I proactively sought legal advice from the House Ethics Committee, who gave me more than one written opinion, along with an additional opinion from a national law firm.\n\n\"Furthermore, we requested a meeting with the Washington D.C. prosecutors to explain the facts and they refused to discuss the case with us or hear our side.\"\n\nThe National Desk reached out to the lawmaker for comment on the matter, but didn't receive a response at the time this article was published.\n\nNBC News, CNN and Fox News, all cited unnamed sources familiar with the matter.\n\nFederal disclosures show that the nine-term congressman traveled to Azerbaijan in 2013. {"uri": "8110466711", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-04", "time": "01:32:22", "dateTime": "2024-05-04T01:32:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-04T01:31:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://www.click2houston.com/news/texas/2024/05/04/with-indictment-us-rep-henry-cuellars-deep-south-texas-ties-will-again-be-tested/", "title": "With indictment, U.S. Rep. Henry Cuellar's deep South Texas ties will again be tested", "body": "Sign up for The Brief, The Texas Tribune's daily newsletter that keeps readers up to speed on the most essential Texas news.\n\nRecommended Videos\n\nMcALLEN -- When federal agents raided the home and offices of U.S. Rep. Henry Cuellar, D-Laredo, just weeks before a competitive primary election in 2022, Democrats rallied behind him and he went on to secure another term in office. Now facing charges of bribery and money laundering, he might need them to do the same.\n\nFriday's indictment threw a wrench in Cuellar and his party's South Texas plans for 2024, a year in which he had been expected to cruise to reelection. He immediately declared he's still running for reelection. But now there are calls from Republicans for him to resign and expressions of frustration from progressives who felt Democratic Party leaders shouldn't have stuck with him when the first hints of legal trouble emerged two years ago.\n\nMeanwhile, allies in his South Texas district, including some top local leaders, remain stalwart in their support of Cuellar. Some are referring to a familiar refrain: \"Innocent until proven guilty.\"\n\n\"Anyone can charge you with anything, it doesn't necessarily mean that it's a fact,\" said Starr County Judge Eloy Vera, who added that he didn't think the allegations would hurt Cuellar's chances at reelection in November.\n\nVera's response highlights Cuellar's deep roots in the district. In Laredo, his hometown, Cuellar's brother and sister have both held local elected office.\n\nWhen federal investigators searched his home in 2022, it was only a few weeks before a hard-fought primary against progressive candidate Jessica Cisneros, a Laredo-based immigration attorney who lambasted Cuellar as \"Donald Trump's favorite Democrat.\" Cisneros targeted Cuellar, known as one of the most moderate Democrats in Congress, for his opposition to abortion rights and fundraising he did for colleagues on the other side of the aisle.\n\nBut then-House Speaker Nancy Pelosi rallied to his side, and Cuellar ended up winning in the primary runoff by 0.6 percentage points. Months later, he won the general election by a surprisingly large 13-percentage-point margin.\n\nOn Friday, many of Cuellar's progressive critics decried that establishment support, saying it put a Democratic seat -- and the party's hopes of a House majority -- at risk two years later. And they argued it would make it harder to use Donald Trump's criminal indictments against him if the party is maintaining its support of Cuellar.\n\nCuellar is accused of accepting almost $600,000 in bribes from the country of Azerbaijan and a Mexican bank in exchange for political favors in Congress.\n\n[Texas Congressman Henry Cuellar indicted on charges of bribery, money laundering]\n\nHe maintained his innocence Friday, and Democratic leadership appeared to stick with him -- at least for now. Because of party rules, Cuellar was temporarily stripped of his leadership role on the powerful Homeland Security Appropriations Subcommittee in the House. But Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries stressed in a statement on Friday that Cuellar \"has admirably devoted his career to public service and is a valued Member of the House Democratic Caucus.\"\n\n\"Like any American, Congressman Cuellar is entitled to his day in court and the presumption of innocence throughout the legal process,\" Jeffries said.\n\nThe National Republican Congressional Committee, meanwhile, immediately called for Cuellar to resign.\n\n\"If his colleagues truly believe in putting 'people over politics,' they will call on him to resign. If not - they are hypocrites whose statements about public service aren't worth the paper they're written on,\" NRCC spokesperson Delanie Bomar said in a statement.\n\nTwo Republican challengers will face off in a May 28 runoff for the chance to challenge Cuellar in the general election: Jay Furman and Lazaro Garza.\n\nFurman issued a video statement shortly after the news of a potential indictment, blasting Cuellar as being part of an establishment that is \"selling us to other nations.\"\n\n\"They're trading us for their deep pockets and their forever policies that are against the values of South Texas,\" Furman said. \"Exciting that maybe one of them will get their due.\"\n\nIn a Facebook post on Friday, Garza said: \"There is no place for corruption in Congress!\"\n\nBut unseating Cuellar remains a big challenge. In nearly 20 years representing District 28 -- a district that stretches from the Texas-Mexico border from Webb County to Starr County, and then runs north to southeast San Antonio -- Cuellar has sowed deep ties. More often than most of the congressmen and women who serve the region, Cuellar has held press conferences with local officials to celebrate funding he helped secure for local projects.\n\nVera, the county judge, said Cuellar is conscientious about their needs and is available to them any time they call.\n\n\"He's delivered. I've got nothing but praise for that man,\" Vera said.\n\nWebb County Democratic Party Chair Sylvia Bruni says there is no denying Cuellar has been influential and brought millions of dollars into the district.\n\n\"I think the record is going to show that he's historically been very, very valuable,\" Bruni said. \"He's managed to work on both sides of the aisle which is something he takes great pride in.\"\n\nBruni said the party would continue advocating for every Democrat on the ballot, including Cuellar, though she acknowledged the indictment complicated their efforts.\n\n\"What is surfacing regarding Congressman Cuellar is certainly distressing, casting a dark cloud over all our sincerest efforts on behalf of our community,\" she said in a statement to Webb County Democrats. Still, she wrote, \"our WCDP will remain quiet regarding the allegations, presuming innocence, and trusting the Justice System to work fairly.\"\n\nIn an interview, Bruni added that Webb County remained a Democratic stronghold and she would count on voters to vote Democrat during a time she described as \"being on the brink of losing our democracy.\"\n\nHeading into November, Cuellar appeared to be on secure footing before Friday, with Republicans focusing their efforts in South Texas on two other congressional seats: Flipping District 15, currently held by first-term U.S. Rep. Monica De La Cruz, R-Edinburg, and holding onto District 34 held by U.S. Rep. Vicente Gonzalez, D-McAllen.\n\nHowever, Jack Byhan, a political scientist at Texas A&M International University in Laredo, is not convinced Cuellar will weather the political storm.\n\n\"With something like this, it's the swing voters that are going to play a major role,\" he said. \"His loyal supporters are going to vote for him anyway and his loyal critics are going to vote against him anyway.\"\n\nHis ability and willingness to reach across the aisle to work with Republicans could help explain why he's been in office for so long, said Byhan.\n\n\"He's a good politician in terms of reading his constituency,\" Byhan said, noting the constituency in South Texas is predominantly Hispanic and tends to hold socially conservative views.\n\nThough she ultimately failed in her bids, Byhan said his opponent Cisneros' surprising performance in 2022 indicated Cuellar isn't as beloved as his supporters would like to believe.\n\n\"We were surprised at how well she did given her inexperience so I think that is a sign that he's acquiring a few more loyal critics,\" Byhan said.\n\nReporting in the Rio Grande Valley is supported in part by the Methodist Healthcare Ministries of South Texas, Inc.\n\nDisclosure: Facebook and Texas A&M International University have been financial supporters of The Texas Tribune, a nonprofit, nonpartisan news organization that is funded in part by donations from members, foundations and corporate sponsors. Financial supporters play no role in the Tribune's journalism. Find a complete list of them here.\n\nWe've got big things in store for you at The Texas Tribune Festival, happening Sept. 5-7 in downtown Austin. Cuellar Swears He's Innocent After Report of Imminent Indictment", "body": "Cuellar, who's represented South Texas in Congress for two decades, wrote in his statement that \"everything I have done in Congress has been to serve the people\" and that what he did was \"consistent with the actions of many of my colleagues and in the interest of the American people.\"\n\nThe imminent indictment may be related to a federal probe into Azerbaijan and a group of U.S. businessmen who have ties to the country. Federal agents raided Cuellar's house and office in 2022 as part of that probe, but Cuellar tamped down the controversy by claiming he wasn't the subject of the investigation but that he'd agreed to cooperate with authorities.\n\nCuellar previously served as a co-chair of the Congressional Azerbaijan Caucus. It's unclear what, exactly, Cuellar has been accused of and what charges he might face.\n\nA source told NBC News that Cuellar's staff were phoning other member offices Friday seeking advice on how to handle the situation.\n\nIn Cuellar's statement, he hinted that a potential indictment may also involve his wife, Imelda Cuellar.\n\n\"I want to be clear that both my wife and I are innocent of these allegations,\" he said.\n\nHe later dedicated an entire paragraph to defending his wife's character.\n\n\"On top of being an amazing wife and mother, she's an accomplished businesswoman with two degrees,\" he said. \"She spent her career working with banking, tax, and consulting. The allegation that she is anything but qualified and hard working is both wrong and offensive.\"\n\nThe budding scandal hasn't shaken Cuellar's confidence in winning re-election in November, however, as he closed his statement by saying: \"Let me be clear, I'm running for reelection and will win this November.\"", "source": {"uri": "thedailybeast.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Daily {"uri": "8110499376", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-04", "time": "03:25:05", "dateTime": "2024-05-04T03:25:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-04T02:20:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/indictment-u-rep-henry-cuellar-011723073.html", "title": "With indictment, U.S. Rep. Henry Cuellar's deep South Texas ties will again be tested", "body": "McALLEN -- When federal agents raided the home and offices of U.S. Rep. Henry Cuellar, D-Laredo, just weeks before a competitive primary election in 2022, Democrats rallied behind him and he went on to secure another term in office. Now facing charges of bribery and money laundering, he might need them to do the same.\n\nFriday's indictment threw a wrench in Cuellar and his party's South Texas plans for 2024, a year in which he had been expected to cruise to reelection. He immediately declared he's still running for reelection. But now there are calls from Republicans for him to resign and expressions of frustration from progressives who felt Democratic Party leaders shouldn't have stuck with him when the first hints of legal trouble emerged two years ago.\n\nMeanwhile, allies in his South Texas district, including some top local leaders, remain stalwart in their support of Cuellar. Some are referring to a familiar refrain: \"Innocent until proven guilty.\"\n\n\"Anyone can charge you with anything, it doesn't necessarily mean that it's a fact,\" said Starr County Judge Eloy Vera, who added that he didn't think the allegations would hurt Cuellar's chances at reelection in November.\n\nVera's response highlights Cuellar's deep roots in the district. In Laredo, his hometown, Cuellar's brother and sister have both held local elected office.\n\nWhen federal investigators searched his home in 2022, it was only a few weeks before a hard-fought primary against progressive candidate Jessica Cisneros, a Laredo-based immigration attorney who lambasted Cuellar as \"Donald Trump's favorite Democrat.\" Cisneros targeted Cuellar, known as one of the most moderate Democrats in Congress, for his opposition to abortion rights and fundraising he did for colleagues on the other side of the aisle.\n\nBut then-House Speaker Nancy Pelosi rallied to his side, and Cuellar ended up winning in the primary runoff by 0.6 percentage points. Months later, he won the general election by a surprisingly large 13-percentage-point margin.\n\nOn Friday, many of Cuellar's progressive critics decried that establishment support, saying it put a Democratic seat -- and the party's hopes of a House majority -- at risk two years later. And they argued it would make it harder to use Donald Trump's criminal indictments against him if the party is maintaining its support of Cuellar.\n\nCuellar is accused of accepting almost $600,000 in bribes from the country of Azerbaijan and a Mexican bank in exchange for political favors in Congress.\n\n[Texas Congressman Henry Cuellar indicted on charges of bribery, money laundering]\n\nHe maintained his innocence Friday, and Democratic leadership appeared to stick with him -- at least for now. Because of party rules, Cuellar was temporarily stripped of his leadership role on the powerful Homeland Security Appropriations Subcommittee in the House. But Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries stressed in a statement on Friday that Cuellar \"has admirably devoted his career to public service and is a valued Member of the House Democratic Caucus.\"\n\n\"Like any American, Congressman Cuellar is entitled to his day in court and the presumption of innocence throughout the legal process,\" Jeffries said.\n\nThe National Republican Congressional Committee, meanwhile, immediately called for Cuellar to resign.\n\n\"If his colleagues truly believe in putting 'people over politics,' they will call on him to resign. If not - they are hypocrites whose statements about public service aren't worth the paper they're written on,\" NRCC spokesperson Delanie Bomar said in a statement.\n\nTwo Republican challengers will face off in a May 28 runoff for the chance to challenge Cuellar in the general election: Jay Furman and Lazaro Garza.\n\nFurman issued a video statement shortly after the news of a potential indictment, blasting Cuellar as being part of an establishment that is \"selling us to other nations.\"\n\n\"They're trading us for their deep pockets and their forever policies that are against the values of South Texas,\" Furman said. \"Exciting that maybe one of them will get their due.\"\n\nIn a Facebook post on Friday, Garza said: \"There is no place for corruption in Congress!\"\n\nBut unseating Cuellar remains a big challenge. In nearly 20 years representing District 28 -- a district that stretches from the Texas-Mexico border from Webb County to Starr County, and then runs north to southeast San Antonio -- Cuellar has sowed deep ties. More often than most of the congressmen and women who serve the region, Cuellar has held press conferences with local officials to celebrate funding he helped secure for local projects.\n\nVera, the county judge, said Cuellar is conscientious about their needs and is available to them any time they call.\n\n\"He's delivered. I've got nothing but praise for that man,\" Vera said.\n\nWebb County Democratic Party Chair Sylvia Bruni says there is no denying Cuellar has been influential and brought millions of dollars into the district.\n\n\"I think the record is going to show that he's historically been very, very valuable,\" Bruni said. \"He's managed to work on both sides of the aisle which is something he takes great pride in.\"\n\nBruni said the party would continue advocating for every Democrat on the ballot, including Cuellar, though she acknowledged the indictment complicated their efforts.\n\n\"What is surfacing regarding Congressman Cuellar is certainly distressing, casting a dark cloud over all our sincerest efforts on behalf of our community,\" she said in a statement to Webb County Democrats. Still, she wrote, \"our WCDP will remain quiet regarding the allegations, presuming innocence, and trusting the Justice System to work fairly.\"\n\nIn an interview, Bruni added that Webb County remained a Democratic stronghold and she would count on voters to vote Democrat during a time she described as \"being on the brink of losing our democracy.\"\n\nHeading into November, Cuellar appeared to be on secure footing before Friday, with Republicans focusing their efforts in South Texas on two other congressional seats: Flipping District 15, currently held by first-term U.S. Rep. Monica De La Cruz, R-Edinburg, and holding onto District 34 held by U.S. Rep. Vicente Gonzalez, D-McAllen.\n\nHowever, Jack Byhan, a political scientist at Texas A&M International University in Laredo, is not convinced Cuellar will weather the political storm.\n\n\"With something like this, it's the swing voters that are going to play a major role,\" he said. \"His loyal supporters are going to vote for him anyway and his loyal critics are going to vote against him anyway.\"\n\nHis ability and willingness to reach across the aisle to work with Republicans could help explain why he's been in office for so long, said Byhan.\n\n\"He's a good politician in terms of reading his constituency,\" Byhan said, noting the constituency in South Texas is predominantly Hispanic and tends to hold socially conservative views.\n\nThough she ultimately failed in her bids, Byhan said his opponent Cisneros' surprising performance in 2022 indicated Cuellar isn't as beloved as his supporters would like to believe.\n\n\"We were surprised at how well she did given her inexperience so I think that is a sign that he's acquiring a few more loyal critics,\" Byhan said.\n\nReporting in the Rio Grande Valley is supported in part by the Methodist Healthcare Ministries of South Texas, Inc.\n\nDisclosure: Facebook and Texas A&M International University have been financial supporters of The Texas Tribune, a nonprofit, nonpartisan news organization that is funded in part by donations from members, foundations and corporate sponsors. Financial supporters play no role in the Tribune's journalism. {"uri": "8110382559", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-03", "time": "23:23:29", "dateTime": "2024-05-03T23:23:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-03T23:22:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://hotair.com/karen-townsend/2024/05/03/texas-democrat-rep-henry-cuellar-indicted-n3787721", "title": "Texas Democrat Rep Henry Cuellar Declares Innocence Ahead of Expected Indictment", "body": "Rep. Henry Cuellar (D-TX) is expected to be indicted today. He has been on the Biden administration's radar for several years, and not in a good way.\n\nCuellar is the only pro-life Democrat in the House. He is openly critical of Biden's border crisis. He has represented Texas's 28th congressional district since 2005. His district extends from the Rio Grande to San Antonio's suburbs.\n\nCuellar is a rare centrist in today's Democrat Party. Progressive Democrats ran candidates against him in 2020 and 2022. This is a story that is breaking on a Friday. It feels like it is meant to bloody up Cuellar in an election cycle.\n\nAbortion is a key issue in President Biden's re-election campaign. Nothing is too extreme for Democrats when it comes to abortion. Cuellar did not make any fans among Team Biden when he declared that abortion is best left up to states, not the federal government.\n\nIn April, he boldly stated his position to Punchbowl.\n\n\"It should be left up to the states,\" Cuellar told us. \"I'm a big believer in the big tent theory and I think [Democrats] should allow people with different religious beliefs when it comes to that.\"\n\nNope. That's not gonna fly in today's Democrat Party.\n\nCuellar does not have any real opposition to his re-election this cycle. Two Republicans are running in a run-off election. Biden carried his district by 7 points in 2020. House Democrats have pledged their support of Cuellar's re-election.\n\nCuellar said he is not dropping out of the race.\n\nAll this goes back to an FBI raid that was conducted at Cuellar's home in Laredo and his local congressional office in January 2022. It happened just a matter of weeks before his primary election. At the time he was in a closely contested race with a progressive candidate, Jessica Cisneros, picked by Justice Democrats to run against him in the primary. She also ran against Cuellar in 2020. The 2020 race was much closer than the 2022 race. He won 56% of the vote in 2022. Justice Democrats are a far-left political action committee. They support the likes of Bernie Sanders, AOC, The Squad, and so on. You get the picture. Cisneros was a former intern with Cuellar's office and is currently an immigration lawyer.\n\nAt the time, I said that the raid and the publicity sure looked like Cuellar's opposition targeting him right before the election with the help of Biden's DOJ. The FBI and the DOJ refused to say what it was that they were investigating. ABC News reported that it had to do with a federal probe into the former Soviet state of Azerbaijan and several U.S. businessmen. A federal grand jury in Washington, D.C. was investigating the matter. Cuellar is a member of the Congressional Azerbaijan Caucus.\n\nCuellar responded to the news of an indictment coming his way.\n\nIn his Friday statement, Cuellar said his actions were \"consistent with the actions of many of my colleagues and in the interest of the American people.\"\n\n\"I want to be clear that both my wife and I are innocent of these allegations,\" Cuellar said without addressing what the allegations were about. \"Before I took any action, I proactively sought legal advice from the House Ethics Committee, who gave me more than one written opinion, along with an additional opinion from a national law firm.\"\n\nThat's the first I've heard of his wife's involvement. Is she a potential target? Cuellar has been told since the FBI raid that he is not a target in the investigation.\n\nSomething is off here. The timing is suspicious in an election year. Cuellar is sideways with the administration and other Democrats on abortion and the open southern border. Biden has completely politicized the DOJ against those who oppose him and his policies. "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://www.newsweek.com/henry-cuellar-texas-democrat-indicted-bribery-azerbaijan-mexico-1897159", "title": "Texas Democrat tried to meet with prosecutors before bribery indictment", "body": "Representative Henry Cuellar, a Democrat from Texas, said this week that he attempted to meet with prosecutors prior to being indicted for allegedly taking nearly $600,000 in bribes.\n\nThe Associated Press reported on Friday that Cuellar was indicted by the U.S. Department of Justice on bribery and conspiracy charges in connection with an investigation into Cuellar's ties to business leaders and Azerbaijan.\n\nAccording to the Associated Press, the indictment against Cuellar alleged that he accepted almost $600,000 in bribes from an energy company controlled by Azerbaijan and a bank in Mexico.\n\nIn a statement obtained by the Associated Press, Cuellar disputed the allegations and said, \"we requested a meeting with the Washington D.C. prosecutors to explain the facts and they refused to discuss the case with us or hear our side.\"\n\n\"\"Everything I have done in Congress has been to serve the people of South Texas,\" the statement said, according to the AP. \"Before I took action, I proactively sought legal advice from the House Ethics Committee, who gave me more than one written opinion, along with an additional opinion from a {"uri": "8110069554", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-03", "time": "17:46:24", "dateTime": "2024-05-03T17:46:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-03T17:45:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://www.ntd.com/democratic-texas-congressman-cuellar-claims-innocence-prior-to-reported-charges_990591.html", "title": "Democratic Texas Congressman Cuellar Claims Innocence Prior to Reported Charges", "body": "Rep. Henry Cuellar (D-Texas) is claiming his innocence in a statement prior to reported incoming indictments, which were first reported by NBC News on Friday, May 3.\n\nMr. Cuellar, who has represented Texas's 28th Congressional District since 2005, said in the statement that he and his wife were both innocent and all of his actions in Congress have \"been to serve the people of South Texas.\"\n\n\"Before I took any action, I proactively sought legal advice from the House Ethics Committee, who gave me more than one written opinion, along with an additional opinion from a national law firm,\" Mr. Cuellar said in the statement obtained by The Epoch Times. \"The actions I took in Congress were consistent with the actions of many of my colleagues and in the interest of the American people.\"\n\nMr. Cuellar's Laredo, Texas, home was raided in 2022 weeks before a primary election, and the congressman claimed his innocence at that time as well.\n\n\"There is an ongoing investigation that will show that there was no wrongdoing on my part,\" Mr. Cuellar said at the time. \"As an attorney, I know firsthand that the legal system is the pillar of our democracy. I pride myself on being your congressman and always doing things honestly, ethically and the right way.\"\n\nMr. Cuellar is seen as a moderate Democrat who has previously criticized President Joe Biden's handling of immigration and border policy. His district includes land that touches the U.S.-Mexico border.\n\nIt is still unclear what allegations Mr. Cuellar is referring to. ABC News reported at the time of the raid that the investigation of the couple and one of Mr. Cuellar's campaign staffers was related to alleged ties to Azerbaijan. The congressman is a member of the Congressional Azerbaijan Caucus.\n\nIn the statement released following the news of his pending indictment, Mr. Cuellar said he had met with prosecutors in Washington to explain \"the facts\" but that they had \"refused to discuss the case\" with him and his wife or \"hear [their] side.\"\n\n\"Imelda and I have been married for 32 years,\" he said. \"On top of being an amazing wife and mother, she's an accomplished businesswoman with two degrees. She spent her career working with banking, tax, and consulting. The allegation that she is anything but qualified and hard working is both wrong and offensive.\"\n\nHe added the allegations, which are still unclear, have been difficult on his family, but with prayer he seeks to overcome them.\n\n\"As the son of migrant workers, I was taught to wake up early and work hard,\" he added. \"That's exactly what I've always done for the people of South Texas. I've devoted my life's work to creating jobs here, improving education, and securing our border.\"\n\nHe said he would not shy away from running for re-election this November and added that he was going \"to win.\"\n\nFBI agents were seen at Mr. Cuellar's home and campaign office on Jan. 19, 2022. Photographs shared by local reporters showed agents at Mr. Cuellar's residence in Laredo removing bags, bins, and at least one computer.\n\nThe FBI said at the time in a statement to media outlets that the bureau \"was present in Laredo conducting court-authorized law enforcement activity,\" without elaborating.\n\nMr. Cuellar, 66, has represented Texas's 28th Congressional District since 2005. {"uri": "8110993385", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-04", "time": "11:01:16", "dateTime": "2024-05-04T11:01:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-04T11:00:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://www.timeslive.co.za/news/world/2024-05-04-us-lawmaker-cuellar-hit-with-bribery-charges-tied-to-azerbaijan-mexican-bank/", "title": "US lawmaker Cuellar hit with bribery charges tied to Azerbaijan, Mexican bank", "body": "U.S. Representative Henry Cuellar and his wife were indicted for allegedly accepting close to $600,000 in bribes in two schemes meant to benefit an Azerbaijani state-owned energy company and an unnamed bank based in Mexico, court papers showed.\n\nThe federal indictment, returned by a grand jury in Texas on Tuesday and unsealed on Friday, said the bribes were laundered through sham consulting contracts into shell companies owned by Imelda Cuellar, the Democratic congressman's wife, from December 2014 through at least November 2021.\n\nIn exchange, it says Henry Cuellar sought to use his public position to influence U.S. foreign policy in Azerbaijan's favor and to pressure U.S. government officials to help the Mexican bank lobby against anti-money laundering enforcement policies and payday lending regulations that threatened its business.\n\nBefore the charges were unsealed, Cuellar issued a statement denying the allegations.\n\n\"Both my wife and I are innocent of these allegations,\" said Cuellar.\n\nOne of the most conservative Democrats in the House of Representatives, Cuellar is seeking an 11th two-year term in the Nov. 5 election. He represents a Texas district that borders Mexico and includes Laredo and parts of San Antonio.\n\nThe 54-page indictment identifies the bank only as \"Foreign Bank-1,\" a Mexico City-based institution that conducts payday lending in the U.S. and is part of a Mexican finance and retail holding company that also owns a Mexican media company.\n\nThat appears to match Grupo Salinas, a sprawling conglomerate controlled by Mexican billionaire Ricardo Salinas, whose business empire includes Banco Azteca. The indictment also provides identifying details of a bank executive who appears to match a recently retired Banco Azteca executive.\n\n\"Right now, we don't have information about this,\" Grupo Salinas executive Luciano Pascoe told Reuters by email in response to a request for comment.\n\nCuellar will step down as the ranking member of the Homeland Security Appropriations subcommittee while the case is pending, said a spokesperson for Democratic House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries.\n\nCuellar's home and campaign office in Laredo were searched by federal law enforcement in January 2022, when Cuellar served as a co-chair of the Congressional Azerbaijan Caucus.\n\nIn that capacity, he and several other members of Congress signed a letter urging Congress to provide humanitarian support to assist people displaced following the war between Azerbaijan and Armenia.\n\nThe indictment cites Cuellar's support for providing funding to Azerbaijan and a pro-Azerbaijan speech he gave on the House floor, among other actions.\n\nCuellar said in his statement he had sought legal advice from the House Ethics Committee and a national law firm.\n\n\"We requested a meeting with the Washington DC prosecutors to explain the facts and they refused to discuss the case with us or to hear our side,\" he added.\n\nThe Justice Department said Cuellar and his wife made initial appearances before a federal magistrate judge in Houston on Friday. They were released on bond.\n\nEach faces 14 counts on charges including conspiracy, bribery, honest services wire fraud, being a public official acting as an agent of a foreign principal, and money laundering.\n\nSeveral of the charges carry a statutory maximum of 20 years in prison.\n\nCuellar is not the only member of Congress facing federal charges.\n\nDemocratic Senator Bob Menendez is awaiting trial on corruption charges in New York, while Republican George Santos last year was expelled from the House while he awaits trial on charges of violating campaign finance laws.", "source": {"uri": "8110235373", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-03", "time": "20:24:26", "dateTime": "2024-05-03T20:24:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-03T20:23:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://www.commondreams.org/news/henry-cuellar", "title": "US Rep. Henry Cuellar and Wife Indicted on Bribery Charges | Common Dreams", "body": "\"In exchange for the bribe payments to Imelda Cuellar, Henry Cuellar agreed to perform official acts in his capacity as a member of Congress,\" the indictment states.\n\nThe U.S. Department of Justice confirmed Friday that Democratic Texas Congressman Henry Cuellar and his wife, Imelda Cuellar, were indicted last week for allegedly \"participating in two schemes involving bribery, unlawful foreign influence, and money laundering.\"\n\nAccording to the indictment, between at least December 2014 and November 2021, the Cuellars allegedly took approximately $600,000 in bribes from a fossil fuel company owned by the Azerbaijani government and an unnamed bank headquartered in Mexico City. The congressman, who has served on Capitol Hill for nearly two decades and is seeking reelection, previously co-chaired the Congressional Azerbaijan Caucus.\n\n\"The bribe payments were laundered, pursuant to sham consulting contracts, through a series of front companies and middlemen into shell companies owned by Imelda Cuellar,\" the document states. \"In exchange for the bribe payments to Imelda Cuellar, Henry Cuellar agreed to perform official acts in his capacity as a member of Congress, to commit acts in violation of his official duties, and to act as an agent of the government of Azerbaijan and [the foreign bank].\"\n\nNBC News first reported early Friday that the Justice Department was expected to release the indictment, which came more than two years after a Federal Bureau of Investigation raid of the couple's Laredo home. Before the document was unsealed, the congressman claimed in a statement that his actions were \"consistent with the actions of many of my colleagues and in the interest of the American people.\"\n\n\"I want to be clear that both my wife and I are innocent of these allegations,\" Cuellar said Friday. \"Before I took any action, I proactively sought legal advice from the House Ethics Committee, who gave me more than one written opinion, along with an additional opinion from a national law firm.\"\n\nThe Cuellars \"made their initial court appearance today before U.S. Magistrate Judge Dena Palermo in Houston,\" the Justice Departmnet said Friday. If convicted of all the charges, the 68-year-old congressman and his 67-year-old wife could face decades in prison.\n\nCongressional Democratic leadership last year endorsed Cuellar for reelection in November, despite his opposition to abortion rights -- a key issue for this cycle at all levels of politics. During the 2022 cycle, after nearly losing to progressive primary challenger Jessica Cisneros, he beat the Republican nominee, Cassy Garcia, 57% to 43%.\n\nA spokesperson for U.S. House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries (D-N.Y.), Christie Stephenson, saidin a Friday statement that \"Henry Cuellar has admirably devoted his career to public service and is a valued member of the House Democratic Caucus. Like any American, Congressman Cuellar is entitled to his day in court and the presumption of innocence throughout the legal process.\"\n\n\"Pursuant to House Democratic Caucus Rule 24, Congressman Cuellar will take leave as ranking member of the Homeland Security Appropriations Subcommittee while this matter is ongoing,\" Stephenson added.\n\nCuellar isn't the only Democrat in Congress battling allegations of corruption and bribery charges. Sen. Bob Menendez (D-N.J.) and his wife, Nadine Menendez, were indicted last September and accused of accepting bribes in the form of \"cash, gold, payments toward a home mortgage, compensation for a low-or-no-show job, a luxury vehicle, and other things of value.\"\n\nThe following month, the Justice Department accused the senator of acting as an unregistered agent for the government of Egypt. Menendez has denied wrongdoing and refused to resign. Although he is not seeking reelection as a Democrat, he has teased a possible independent run if he is exonerated.", "source": {"uri": "commondreams.org", "dataType": "news", "title": "Common Henry Cuellar, the Texas Democrat indicted by the Justice Department?", "body": "The Justice Department released an indictment against Texas Democrat Rep. Henry Cuellar on criminal charges, multiple media outlets reported on Friday.\n\nHere is what we know.\n\nCuellar is serving his tenth term in the U.S. House of Representatives for Texas' 28th congressional district, which includes the cities of Laredo, Rio Grande City, and San Antonio.\n\nAccording to a biography, Cuellar was born in Laredo, Texas, where he earned his associate degree from Laredo Community College before enrolling at Georgetown University in Washington, D.C. He later earned several postgraduate degrees in Texas before he began practicing law in 1981. He also served as a Texas State Representative and Texas Secretary of State before becoming a U.S. Congressman.\n\nHe and his wife, Imelda, and two daughters live in Laredo.\n\nNBC News was the first to report about the expected indictment, stating that Cuellar and his wife are being charged with bribery and money laundering in connection to an Azerbaijani oil and gas company.\n\nNBC News reported that \"The Cuellars allegedly accepted roughly $600,000 in bribes from the two foreign entities in exchange for the congressman performing official acts.\"\n\nThe FBI executed a search warrant at Cuellar's home and campaign office in 2022 but it is unclear if any potential federal charges are related to the raid. Cuellar serves as a co-chair of the Congressional Azerbaijan Caucus.\n\nHis lawyer Joshua Berman said in April that he was informed by the feds that Cuellar was not the focus of the investigation.\n\n\"I want to be clear that both my wife and I are innocent of these allegations,\" Cuellar said in a statement to USA TODAY, indicating his wife Imelda, is also involved.\n\n\"Proactively sought legal advice from the House Ethics Committee, who gave me more than one written opinion, along with an additional opinion from a national law firm,\" he said. \"Furthermore, we requested a meeting with the Washington D.C. prosecutors to explain the facts and they refused to discuss the case with us or to hear our side.\"\n\nThe National Republican Congressional Committee, the campaign arm of House Republicans, swiftly responded to reports of an imminent criminal indictment and urged House Democrats to call on their colleague to resign.\n\n\"Henry Cuellar does not put Texas first, he puts himself first,\" Delanie Bomar, a spokesperson for the NRCC said in a statement. \"If his colleagues truly believe in putting 'people over politics,' they will call on him to resign. If not - they are hypocrites whose statements about public service aren't worth the paper they're written on.\"\n\n-- USA TODAY reporter Ken Tran contributed to this report.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8110126587", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-03", "time": "18:36:59", "dateTime": "2024-05-03T18:36:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-03T18:36:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://thehill.com/homenews/4641800-cuellar-wife-indicted-bribery-charges/", "title": "Cuellar, wife indicted on bribery charges", "body": "Rep. Henry Cuellar (D-Texas) and his wife were indicted Friday on charges related to accepting nearly $600,000 in bribes and laundering the funds.\n\nThe indictment filed by the Justice Department details payments Cuellar allegedly accepted both from an oil company owned by the Azerbaijan government as well as a Mexican bank.\n\n\"The bribe payments were allegedly laundered, pursuant to sham consulting contracts, through a series of front companies and middlemen into shell companies owned by Imelda Cuellar, who performed little to no legitimate work under the contracts,\" DOJ wrote in a press release announcing the indictment in the southern district of Texas.\n\n\"In exchange for the bribes paid by the Azerbaijani oil and gas company, Congressman Cuellar allegedly agreed to use his office to influence U.S. foreign policy in favor of Azerbaijan. In exchange for the bribes paid by the Mexican bank, Congressman Cuellar allegedly agreed to influence legislative activity and to advise and pressure high-ranking U.S. Executive Branch officials regarding measures beneficial to the bank.\"\n\nCuellar denied he or his wife did anything wrong in a statement issued before the charges were unsealed.\n\n\"I want to be clear that both my wife and I are innocent of these allegations. Everything I have done in Congress has been to serve the people of South Texas,\" Cuellar said in a statement through his campaign.\n\n\"Before I took any action, I proactively sought legal advice from the House Ethics Committee, who gave me more than one written opinion, along with an additional opinion from a national law firm. The actions I took in Congress were consistent with the actions of many of my colleagues and in the interest of the American people.\"\n\nCuellar, who is a co-chair of the Congressional Azerbaijan Caucus, will have to step down from his post as the ranking member on the House Homeland Security Appropriations Subcommittee, House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries' (D-N.Y) office noted in a statement nodding to House rules.\n\n\"Henry Cuellar has admirably devoted his career to public service and is a valued Member of the House Democratic Caucus. Like any American, Congressman Cuellar is entitled to his day in court and the presumption of innocence throughout the legal process,\" Jeffries spokeswoman Christie Stephenson said in the statement.\n\nCuellar also noted earlier Friday that he still plans to seek reelection.\n\nThe indictment makes Cuellar the second lawmaker in the last year to face bribery charges relating to a foreign government alongside his wife. {"uri": "2024-05-345239360", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-04", "time": "21:44:06", "dateTime": "2024-05-04T21:44:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-04T21:43:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.gulf-times.com/article/681826/international/us-lawmaker-hit-with-bribery-charges-tied-to-azerbaijan-mexican-bank", "title": "US lawmaker hit with bribery charges tied to Azerbaijan, Mexican bank", "body": "US Representative Henry Cuellar and his wife were indicted for allegedly accepting close to $600,000 in bribes in two schemes meant to benefit an Azerbaijani state-owned energy company and an unnamed bank based in Mexico, court papers showed.\n\nThe federal indictment, returned by a grand jury in Texas on Tuesday and unsealed on Friday, said the bribes were laundered through sham consulting contracts into shell companies owned by Imelda Cuellar, the Democratic congressman's wife, from December 2014 through at least November 2021.\n\nIn exchange, it says Henry Cuellar sought to use his public position to influence US foreign policy in Azerbaijan's favour and to pressure US government officials to help the Mexican bank lobby against anti-money laundering enforcement policies and payday lending regulations that threatened its business.\n\nBefore the charges were unsealed, Cuellar issued a statement denying the allegations.\n\n\"Both my wife and I are innocent of these allegations,\" said Cuellar.\n\nOne of the most conservative Democrats in the House of Representatives, Cuellar is seeking an 11th two-year term in the November 5 election. He represents a Texas district that borders Mexico and includes Laredo and parts of San Antonio.\n\nThe 54-page indictment identifies the bank only as \"Foreign Bank-1,\" a Mexico City-based institution that conducts payday lending in the US and is part of a Mexican finance and retail holding company that also owns a Mexican media company.\n\nThat appears to match Grupo Salinas, a sprawling conglomerate controlled by Mexican billionaire Ricardo Salinas, whose business empire includes Banco Azteca. The indictment also provides identifying details of a bank executive who appears to match a recently retired Banco Azteca executive.\n\n\"Right now, we don't have information about this,\" Grupo Salinas executive Luciano Pascoe told Reuters by email in response to a request for comment.\n\nCuellar will step down as the ranking member of the Homeland Security Appropriations subcommittee while the case is pending, said a spokesperson for Democratic House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries.\n\nCuellar's home and campaign office in Laredo were searched by federal law enforcement in January 2022, when Cuellar served as a co-chair of the Congressional Azerbaijan Caucus.\n\nIn that capacity, he and several other members of Congress signed a letter urging Congress to provide humanitarian support to assist people displaced following the war between Azerbaijan and Armenia.\n\nThe indictment cites Cuellar's support for providing funding to Azerbaijan and a pro-Azerbaijan speech he gave on the House floor, among other actions.\n\nCuellar said in his statement he had sought legal advice from the House Ethics Committee and a national law firm.\n\n\"We requested a meeting with the Washington, DC prosecutors to explain the facts and they refused to discuss the case with us or to hear our side,\" he added.\n\nThe Justice Department said Cuellar and his wife made initial appearances before a federal magistrate judge in Houston on Friday. They were released on bond.\n\nEach faces 14 counts on charges including conspiracy, bribery, honest services wire fraud, being a public official acting as an agent of a foreign principal, and money laundering.\n\nSeveral of the charges carry a statutory maximum of 20 years in prison.\n\nCuellar is not the only member of Congress facing federal charges.\n\nDemocratic Senator Bob Menendez is awaiting trial on corruption charges in New York, while Republican George Santos last year was expelled from the House while he awaits trial on charges of violating campaign finance laws.\n\nBoth If found guilty, they could face decades in prison.\n\n\"I want to be clear that both my wife and I are innocent of these allegations,\" Mr Cuellar, 68, said on Friday.\n\nThe couple are each charged with multiple counts of conspiracy, bribery, wire fraud, money laundering and violating a ban on acting as agents of a foreign organisation.\n\nThe justice department said bribes were laundered from 2014-21 via a series of \"sham consulting contracts\" through middlemen and front companies owned by Imelda Cuellar, 67.\n\nIn exchange for the money, the indictment alleges Mr Cuellar agreed to influence US foreign policy in favour of Azerbaijan and push measures beneficial to the bank headquartered in Mexico City, including changes to money-laundering laws and attempts to block regulation of the payday lending industry.\n\nSenator Robert Menendez, a New Jersey Democrat, faces similar charges. He and his wife are accused of taking bribes to benefit Qatar and of acting as an illegal agent of Egypt.\n\nIn the statement released by his office, Mr Cuellar vowed to keep campaigning for re-election in November.\n\n\"Before I took any action, I proactively sought legal advice from the House Ethics Committee, who gave me more than one written opinion, along with an additional opinion from a national law firm,\" he said.\n\n\"The actions I took in Congress were consistent with the actions of many of my colleagues and in the interest of the American people.\"\n\nMr Cuellar was a lawyer and former customs broker before entering politics. He was first elected to Congress in 2004 and is a former co-chair of the Congressional Azerbaijan Caucus.\n\nHakeem Jeffries, Democratic party leader in the House of Representatives, said Mr Cuellar would take a leave of absence from his post on a homeland security subcommittee while the case continues.\n\nMr Cuellar's home and campaign office in Laredo were raided in January 2022.\n\nAuthorities said at the time the raid was part of a federal investigation into Azerbaijan and US businessmen who have links to the country.\n\nMr Cuellar is widely considered a centrist and has been described as the lone anti-abortion House Democrat.\n\nIn 2022, he narrowly survived a primary challenge from a progressive candidate, Jessica Cisneros, who once worked as an intern in his office.", "source": {"uri": "8110563524", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-04", "time": "03:49:24", "dateTime": "2024-05-04T03:49:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-04T03:48:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/politics/2927211-us-lawmaker-cuellar-hit-with-bribery-charges-tied-to-azerbaijan-mexican-bank", "title": "US lawmaker Cuellar hit with bribery charges tied to Azerbaijan, Mexican bank | Politics", "body": "The federal indictment, returned by a grand jury in Texas on Tuesday and unsealed on Friday, said the bribes were laundered through sham consulting contracts into shell companies owned by Imelda Cuellar, the Democratic congressman's wife, from December 2014 through at least November 2021. In exchange, it says Henry Cuellar sought to use his public position to influence U.S. foreign policy in Azerbaijan's favor and to pressure U.S. government officials to help the Mexican bank lobby against anti-money laundering enforcement policies and payday lending regulations that threatened its business.\n\nU.S. Representative Henry Cuellar and his wife were indicted for allegedly accepting close to $600,000 in bribes in two schemes meant to benefit an Azerbaijani state-owned energy company and an unnamed bank based in Mexico, court papers showed. The federal indictment, returned by a grand jury in Texas on Tuesday and unsealed on Friday, said the bribes were laundered through sham consulting contracts into shell companies owned by Imelda Cuellar, the Democratic congressman's wife, from December 2014 through at least November 2021.\n\nIn exchange, it says Henry Cuellar sought to use his public position to influence U.S. foreign policy in Azerbaijan's favor and to pressure U.S. government officials to help the Mexican bank lobby against anti-money laundering enforcement policies and payday lending regulations that threatened its business. Before the charges were unsealed, Cuellar issued a statement denying the allegations.\n\n\"Both my wife and I are innocent of these allegations,\" said Cuellar. One of the most conservative Democrats in the House of Representatives, Cuellar is seeking an 11th two-year term in the Nov. 5 election. He represents a Texas district that borders Mexico and includes Laredo and parts of San Antonio.\n\nThe 54-page indictment identifies the bank only as \"Foreign Bank-1,\" a Mexico City-based institution that conducts payday lending in the U.S. and is part of a Mexican finance and retail holding company that also owns a Mexican media company. That appears to match Grupo Salinas, a sprawling conglomerate controlled by Mexican billionaire Ricardo Salinas, whose business empire includes Banco Azteca. The indictment also provides identifying details of a bank executive who appears to match a recently retired Banco Azteca executive.\n\n\"Right now, we don't have information about this,\" Grupo Salinas executive Luciano Pascoe told Reuters by email in response to a request for comment. Cuellar will step down as the ranking member of the Homeland Security Appropriations subcommittee while the case is pending, said a spokesperson for Democratic House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries.\n\nCuellar's home and campaign office in Laredo were searched by federal law enforcement in January 2022, when Cuellar served as a co-chair of the Congressional Azerbaijan Caucus. In that capacity, he and several other members of Congress signed a letter urging Congress to provide humanitarian support to assist people displaced following the war between Azerbaijan and Armenia.\n\nThe indictment cites Cuellar's support for providing funding to Azerbaijan and a pro-Azerbaijan speech he gave on the House floor, among other actions. Cuellar said in his statement he had sought legal advice from the House Ethics Committee and a national law firm.\n\n\"We requested a meeting with the Washington DC prosecutors to explain the facts and they refused to discuss the case with us or to hear our side,\" he added. The Justice Department said Cuellar and his wife made initial appearances before a federal magistrate judge in Houston on Friday. They were released on bond.\n\nEach faces 14 counts on charges including conspiracy, bribery, honest services wire fraud, being a public official acting as an agent of a foreign principal, and money laundering. Several of the charges carry a statutory maximum of 20 years in prison.\n\nCuellar is not the only member of Congress facing federal charges. Democratic Senator Bob Menendez is awaiting trial on corruption charges in New York, while Republican George Santos last year was expelled from the House while he awaits trial on charges of violating campaign finance laws.\n\nBoth Menendez and Santos deny wrongdoing.\n\n(This story has not been edited by Devdiscourse staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated feed.)", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "2024-05-344445896", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-03", "time": "22:11:29", "dateTime": "2024-05-03T22:11:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-03T20:43:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.rocketnews.com/2024/05/us-congressman-and-wife-charged-with-taking-bribes/", "title": "US congressman and wife charged with taking bribes", "body": "Getty ImagesBy Mike WendlingBBC NewsUS congressman Henry Cuellar and his wife have been charged with accepting around $600,000 (\u00a3478,000) in bribes, the justice department says.It is alleged the couple corruptly received money from an Azerbaijani government-owned oil company and a Mexican bank.The Texas Democrat has denied the charges in a statement.The couple were bailed after appearing in court in Houston. If found guilty, they could face decades in prison.\"I want to be clear that both my wife and I are innocent of these allegations,\" Mr Cuellar, 68, said on Friday. The couple are each charged with multiple counts of conspiracy, bribery, wire fraud, money laundering and violating a ban on acting as agents of a foreign organisation. The justice department said bribes were laundered from 2014-21 via a series of \"sham consulting contracts\" through middlemen and front companies owned by Imelda Cuellar, 67.In exchange for the money, the indictment alleges Mr Cuellar agreed to influence US foreign policy in favour of Azerbaijan and push measures beneficial to the bank headquartered in Mexico City, including changes to money-laundering laws and attempts to block regulation of the payday lending industry. The Cuellar's allegedly used the proceeds from the bribery schemes to pay off a number of debts and make purchased for their family. Among the payments made were more than $58,000 (more than \u00a346,000) in credit card payments, more than $11,000 (more than \u00a38,700) in car payments, $18,000 (more than \u00a314,000) at wholesale stores and $12,000 (more than \u00a39,500) for a custom gown, according to the indictment. Senator Robert Menendez, a New Jersey Democrat, faces similar charges. He and his wife are accused of taking bribes to benefit Qatar and of acting as an illegal agent of Egypt.In the statement released by his office, Mr Cuellar vowed to keep campaigning for re-election in November.\"Before I took any action, I proactively sought legal advice from the House Ethics Committee, who gave me more than one written opinion, along with an additional opinion from a national law firm,\" he said. \"The actions I took in Congress were consistent with the actions of many of my colleagues and in the interest of the American people.\"Mr Cuellar was a lawyer and former customs broker before entering politics. He was first elected to Congress in 2004 and is a former co-chair of the Congressional Azerbaijan Caucus. Hakeem Jeffries, Democratic party leader in the House of Representatives, said Mr Cuellar would take a leave of absence from his post on a homeland security subcommittee while the case continues. Mr Cuellar's home and campaign office in Laredo were raided in January 2022. Authorities said at the time the raid was part of a federal investigation into Azerbaijan and US businessmen who have links to the country.Mr Cuellar is widely considered a centrist and has been described as the lone anti-abortion House Democrat. In 2022, he narrowly survived a primary challenge from a progressive candidate, Jessica Cisneros, who once worked as an intern in his office.
